28@_api.define_aliases({

35class Patch(artist.Artist):
36 """
37 A patch is a 2D artist with a face color and an edge color.
38
39 If any of *edgecolor*, *facecolor*, *linewidth*, or *antialiased*
40 are *None*, they default to their rc params setting.
41 """
42 zorder = 1
43
44 # Whether to draw an edge by default. Set on a
45 # subclass-by-subclass basis.
46 _edge_default = False
47
48 def __init__(self, *,
49 edgecolor=None,
50 facecolor=None,
51 color=None,
52 linewidth=None,
53 linestyle=None,
54 antialiased=None,
55 hatch=None,
56 fill=True,
57 capstyle=None,
58 joinstyle=None,
59 **kwargs):
60 """
61 The following kwarg properties are supported
62
63 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
64 """
65 super().__init__()
66
67 if linestyle is None:
68 linestyle = "solid"
69 if capstyle is None:
70 capstyle = CapStyle.butt
71 if joinstyle is None:
72 joinstyle = JoinStyle.miter
73
74 self._hatch_color = colors.to_rgba(mpl.rcParams['hatch.color'])
75 self._hatch_linewidth = mpl.rcParams['hatch.linewidth']
76 self._fill = bool(fill) # needed for set_facecolor call
77 if color is not None:
78 if edgecolor is not None or facecolor is not None:
79 _api.warn_external(
80 "Setting the 'color' property will override "
81 "the edgecolor or facecolor properties.")
82 self.set_color(color)
83 else:
84 self.set_edgecolor(edgecolor)
85 self.set_facecolor(facecolor)
86
87 self._linewidth = 0
88 self._unscaled_dash_pattern = (0, None) # offset, dash
89 self._dash_pattern = (0, None) # offset, dash (scaled by linewidth)
90
91 self.set_linestyle(linestyle)
92 self.set_linewidth(linewidth)
93 self.set_antialiased(antialiased)
94 self.set_hatch(hatch)
95 self.set_capstyle(capstyle)
96 self.set_joinstyle(joinstyle)
97
98 if len(kwargs):
99 self._internal_update(kwargs)
100
101 def get_verts(self):
102 """
103 Return a copy of the vertices used in this patch.
104
105 If the patch contains BÃ©zier curves, the curves will be interpolated by
106 line segments. To access the curves as curves, use `get_path`.
107 """
108 trans = self.get_transform()
109 path = self.get_path()
110 polygons = path.to_polygons(trans)
111 if len(polygons):
112 return polygons[0]
113 return []
114
115 def _process_radius(self, radius):
116 if radius is not None:
117 return radius
118 if isinstance(self._picker, Number):
119 _radius = self._picker
120 else:
121 if self.get_edgecolor()[3] == 0:
122 _radius = 0
123 else:
124 _radius = self.get_linewidth()
125 return _radius
126
127 def contains(self, mouseevent, radius=None):
128 """
129 Test whether the mouse event occurred in the patch.
130
131 Parameters
132 ----------
133 mouseevent : `~matplotlib.backend_bases.MouseEvent`
134 Where the user clicked.
135
136 radius : float, optional
137 Additional margin on the patch in target coordinates of
138 `.Patch.get_transform`. See `.Path.contains_point` for further
139 details.
140
141 If `None`, the default value depends on the state of the object:
142
143 - If `.Artist.get_picker` is a number, the default
144 is that value. This is so that picking works as expected.
145 - Otherwise if the edge color has a non-zero alpha, the default
146 is half of the linewidth. This is so that all the colored
147 pixels are "in" the patch.
148 - Finally, if the edge has 0 alpha, the default is 0. This is
149 so that patches without a stroked edge do not have points
150 outside of the filled region report as "in" due to an
151 invisible edge.
152
153
154 Returns
155 -------
156 (bool, empty dict)
157 """
158 if self._different_canvas(mouseevent):
159 return False, {}
160 radius = self._process_radius(radius)
161 codes = self.get_path().codes
162 if codes is not None:
163 vertices = self.get_path().vertices
164 # if the current path is concatenated by multiple sub paths.
165 # get the indexes of the starting code(MOVETO) of all sub paths
166 idxs, = np.where(codes == Path.MOVETO)
167 # Don't split before the first MOVETO.
168 idxs = idxs[1:]
169 subpaths = map(
170 Path, np.split(vertices, idxs), np.split(codes, idxs))
171 else:
172 subpaths = [self.get_path()]
173 inside = any(
174 subpath.contains_point(
175 (mouseevent.x, mouseevent.y), self.get_transform(), radius)
176 for subpath in subpaths)
177 return inside, {}
178
179 def contains_point(self, point, radius=None):
180 """
181 Return whether the given point is inside the patch.
182
183 Parameters
184 ----------
185 point : (float, float)
186 The point (x, y) to check, in target coordinates of
187 ``.Patch.get_transform()``. These are display coordinates for patches
188 that are added to a figure or Axes.
189 radius : float, optional
190 Additional margin on the patch in target coordinates of
191 `.Patch.get_transform`. See `.Path.contains_point` for further
192 details.
193
194 If `None`, the default value depends on the state of the object:
195
196 - If `.Artist.get_picker` is a number, the default
197 is that value. This is so that picking works as expected.
198 - Otherwise if the edge color has a non-zero alpha, the default
199 is half of the linewidth. This is so that all the colored
200 pixels are "in" the patch.
201 - Finally, if the edge has 0 alpha, the default is 0. This is
202 so that patches without a stroked edge do not have points
203 outside of the filled region report as "in" due to an
204 invisible edge.
205
206 Returns
207 -------
208 bool
209
210 Notes
211 -----
212 The proper use of this method depends on the transform of the patch.
213 Isolated patches do not have a transform. In this case, the patch
214 creation coordinates and the point coordinates match. The following
215 example checks that the center of a circle is within the circle
216
217 >>> center = 0, 0
218 >>> c = Circle(center, radius=1)
219 >>> c.contains_point(center)
220 True
221
222 The convention of checking against the transformed patch stems from
223 the fact that this method is predominantly used to check if display
224 coordinates (e.g. from mouse events) are within the patch. If you want
225 to do the above check with data coordinates, you have to properly
226 transform them first:
227
228 >>> center = 0, 0
229 >>> c = Circle(center, radius=3)
230 >>> plt.gca().add_patch(c)
231 >>> transformed_interior_point = c.get_data_transform().transform((0, 2))
232 >>> c.contains_point(transformed_interior_point)
233 True
234
235 """
236 radius = self._process_radius(radius)
237 return self.get_path().contains_point(point,
238 self.get_transform(),
239 radius)
240
241 def contains_points(self, points, radius=None):
242 """
243 Return whether the given points are inside the patch.
244
245 Parameters
246 ----------
247 points : (N, 2) array
248 The points to check, in target coordinates of
249 ``self.get_transform()``. These are display coordinates for patches
250 that are added to a figure or Axes. Columns contain x and y values.
251 radius : float, optional
252 Additional margin on the patch in target coordinates of
253 `.Patch.get_transform`. See `.Path.contains_point` for further
254 details.
255
256 If `None`, the default value depends on the state of the object:
257
258 - If `.Artist.get_picker` is a number, the default
259 is that value. This is so that picking works as expected.
260 - Otherwise if the edge color has a non-zero alpha, the default
261 is half of the linewidth. This is so that all the colored
262 pixels are "in" the patch.
263 - Finally, if the edge has 0 alpha, the default is 0. This is
264 so that patches without a stroked edge do not have points
265 outside of the filled region report as "in" due to an
266 invisible edge.
267
268 Returns
269 -------
270 length-N bool array
271
272 Notes
273 -----
274 The proper use of this method depends on the transform of the patch.
275 See the notes on `.Patch.contains_point`.
276 """
277 radius = self._process_radius(radius)
278 return self.get_path().contains_points(points,
279 self.get_transform(),
280 radius)

282 def update_from(self, other):
283 # docstring inherited.
284 super().update_from(other)
285 # For some properties we don't need or don't want to go through the
286 # getters/setters, so we just copy them directly.
287 self._edgecolor = other._edgecolor
288 self._facecolor = other._facecolor
289 self._original_edgecolor = other._original_edgecolor
290 self._original_facecolor = other._original_facecolor
291 self._fill = other._fill
292 self._hatch = other._hatch
293 self._hatch_color = other._hatch_color
294 self._unscaled_dash_pattern = other._unscaled_dash_pattern
295 self.set_linewidth(other._linewidth) # also sets scaled dashes
296 self.set_transform(other.get_data_transform())
297 # If the transform of other needs further initialization, then it will
298 # be the case for this artist too.
299 self._transformSet = other.is_transform_set()

362 def _set_edgecolor(self, color):
363 set_hatch_color = True
364 if color is None:
365 if (mpl.rcParams['patch.force_edgecolor'] or
366 not self._fill or self._edge_default):
367 color = mpl.rcParams['patch.edgecolor']
368 else:
369 color = 'none'
370 set_hatch_color = False
371

373 if set_hatch_color:
374 self._hatch_color = self._edgecolor
375 self.stale = True

444 def set_linestyle(self, ls):
445 """
446 Set the patch linestyle.
447
448 ========================================== =================
449 linestyle description
450 ========================================== =================
451 ``'-'`` or ``'solid'`` solid line
452 ``'--'`` or ``'dashed'`` dashed line
453 ``'-.'`` or ``'dashdot'`` dash-dotted line
454 ``':'`` or ``'dotted'`` dotted line
455 ``'none'``, ``'None'``, ``' '``, or ``''`` draw nothing
456 ========================================== =================
457
458 Alternatively a dash tuple of the following form can be provided::
459
460 (offset, onoffseq)
461
462 where ``onoffseq`` is an even length tuple of on and off ink in points.
463
464 Parameters
465 ----------
466 ls : {'-', '--', '-.', ':', '', (offset, on-off-seq), ...}
467 The line style.
468 """
469 if ls is None:
470 ls = "solid"
471 if ls in [' ', '', 'none']:
472 ls = 'None'
473 self._linestyle = ls
474 self._unscaled_dash_pattern = mlines._get_dash_pattern(ls)
475 self._dash_pattern = mlines._scale_dashes(
476 *self._unscaled_dash_pattern, self._linewidth)
477 self.stale = True
478

541 def set_hatch(self, hatch):
542 r"""
543 Set the hatching pattern.
544
545 *hatch* can be one of::
546
547 / - diagonal hatching
548 \ - back diagonal
549 | - vertical
550 - - horizontal
551 + - crossed
552 x - crossed diagonal
553 o - small circle
554 O - large circle
555 . - dots
556 * - stars
557
558 Letters can be combined, in which case all the specified
559 hatchings are done. If same letter repeats, it increases the
560 density of hatching of that pattern.
561
562 Parameters
563 ----------
564 hatch : {'/', '\\', '|', '-', '+', 'x', 'o', 'O', '.', '*'}
565 """
566 # Use validate_hatch(list) after deprecation.
567 mhatch._validate_hatch_pattern(hatch)
568 self._hatch = hatch
569 self.stale = True
570
571 def get_hatch(self):
572 """Return the hatching pattern."""
573 return self._hatch
574
575 def set_hatch_linewidth(self, lw):
576 """Set the hatch linewidth."""
577 self._hatch_linewidth = lw
578
579 def get_hatch_linewidth(self):
580 """Return the hatch linewidth."""
581 return self._hatch_linewidth

583 def _draw_paths_with_artist_properties(
584 self, renderer, draw_path_args_list):
585 """
586 ``draw()`` helper factored out for sharing with `FancyArrowPatch`.
587
588 Configure *renderer* and the associated graphics context *gc*
589 from the artist properties, then repeatedly call
590 ``renderer.draw_path(gc, *draw_path_args)`` for each tuple
591 *draw_path_args* in *draw_path_args_list*.
592 """
593
594 renderer.open_group('patch', self.get_gid())
595 gc = renderer.new_gc()
596
597 gc.set_foreground(self._edgecolor, isRGBA=True)
598
599 lw = self._linewidth
600 if self._edgecolor[3] == 0 or self._linestyle == 'None':
601 lw = 0
602 gc.set_linewidth(lw)
603 gc.set_dashes(*self._dash_pattern)
604 gc.set_capstyle(self._capstyle)
605 gc.set_joinstyle(self._joinstyle)
606
607 gc.set_antialiased(self._antialiased)
608 self._set_gc_clip(gc)
609 gc.set_url(self._url)
610 gc.set_snap(self.get_snap())
611
612 gc.set_alpha(self._alpha)
613
614 if self._hatch:
615 gc.set_hatch(self._hatch)
616 gc.set_hatch_color(self._hatch_color)
617 gc.set_hatch_linewidth(self._hatch_linewidth)
618
619 if self.get_sketch_params() is not None:
620 gc.set_sketch_params(*self.get_sketch_params())
621
622 if self.get_path_effects():
623 from matplotlib.patheffects import PathEffectRenderer
624 renderer = PathEffectRenderer(self.get_path_effects(), renderer)
625
626 for draw_path_args in draw_path_args_list:
627 renderer.draw_path(gc, *draw_path_args)
628
629 gc.restore()
630 renderer.close_group('patch')
631 self.stale = False
632
633 @artist.allow_rasterization
634 def draw(self, renderer):
635 # docstring inherited
636 if not self.get_visible():
637 return
638 path = self.get_path()
639 transform = self.get_transform()
640 tpath = transform.transform_path_non_affine(path)
641 affine = transform.get_affine()
642 self._draw_paths_with_artist_properties(
643 renderer,
644 [(tpath, affine,
645 # Work around a bug in the PDF and SVG renderers, which
646 # do not draw the hatches if the facecolor is fully
647 # transparent, but do if it is None.
648 self._facecolor if self._facecolor[3] else None)])
649
650 def get_path(self):
651 """Return the path of this patch."""
652 raise NotImplementedError('Derived must override')

655 return self.get_path().get_extents(self.get_transform())

659 x = self.convert_xunits(xy[0])
660 y = self.convert_yunits(xy[1])
661 return x, y

664class Shadow(Patch):
665 def __str__(self):
666 return f"Shadow({self.patch})"
667
668 @_docstring.interpd
669 def __init__(self, patch, ox, oy, *, shade=0.7, **kwargs):
670 """
671 Create a shadow of the given *patch*.
672
673 By default, the shadow will have the same face color as the *patch*,
674 but darkened. The darkness can be controlled by *shade*.
675
676 Parameters
677 ----------
678 patch : `~matplotlib.patches.Patch`
679 The patch to create the shadow for.
680 ox, oy : float
681 The shift of the shadow in data coordinates, scaled by a factor
682 of dpi/72.
683 shade : float, default: 0.7
684 How the darkness of the shadow relates to the original color. If 1, the
685 shadow is black, if 0, the shadow has the same color as the *patch*.
686
687 .. versionadded:: 3.8
688
689 **kwargs
690 Properties of the shadow patch. Supported keys are:
691
692 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
693 """
694 super().__init__()
695 self.patch = patch
696 self._ox, self._oy = ox, oy
697 self._shadow_transform = transforms.Affine2D()
698
699 self.update_from(self.patch)
700 if not 0 <= shade <= 1:
701 raise ValueError("shade must be between 0 and 1.")
702 color = (1 - shade) * np.asarray(colors.to_rgb(self.patch.get_facecolor()))
703 self.update({'facecolor': color, 'edgecolor': color, 'alpha': 0.5,
704 # Place shadow patch directly behind the inherited patch.
705 'zorder': np.nextafter(self.patch.zorder, -np.inf),
706 **kwargs})
707
708 def _update_transform(self, renderer):
709 ox = renderer.points_to_pixels(self._ox)
710 oy = renderer.points_to_pixels(self._oy)
711 self._shadow_transform.clear().translate(ox, oy)
712
713 def get_path(self):
714 return self.patch.get_path()
715
716 def get_patch_transform(self):
717 return self.patch.get_patch_transform() + self._shadow_transform
718
719 def draw(self, renderer):
720 self._update_transform(renderer)
721 super().draw(renderer)

724class Rectangle(Patch):
725 """
726 A rectangle defined via an anchor point *xy* and its *width* and *height*.
727
728 The rectangle extends from ``xy[0]`` to ``xy[0] + width`` in x-direction
729 and from ``xy[1]`` to ``xy[1] + height`` in y-direction. ::
730
731 : +------------------+
732 : | |
733 : height |
734 : | |
735 : (xy)---- width -----+
736
737 One may picture *xy* as the bottom left corner, but which corner *xy* is
738 actually depends on the direction of the axis and the sign of *width*
739 and *height*; e.g. *xy* would be the bottom right corner if the x-axis
740 was inverted or if *width* was negative.
741 """
742
743 def __str__(self):
744 pars = self._x0, self._y0, self._width, self._height, self.angle
745 fmt = "Rectangle(xy=(%g, %g), width=%g, height=%g, angle=%g)"
746 return fmt % pars
747
748 @_docstring.interpd
749 def __init__(self, xy, width, height, *,
750 angle=0.0, rotation_point='xy', **kwargs):
751 """
752 Parameters
753 ----------
754 xy : (float, float)
755 The anchor point.
756 width : float
757 Rectangle width.
758 height : float
759 Rectangle height.
760 angle : float, default: 0
761 Rotation in degrees anti-clockwise about the rotation point.
762 rotation_point : {'xy', 'center', (number, number)}, default: 'xy'
763 If ``'xy'``, rotate around the anchor point. If ``'center'`` rotate
764 around the center. If 2-tuple of number, rotate around this
765 coordinate.
766
767 Other Parameters
768 ----------------
769 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Patch` properties
770 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
771 """
772 super().__init__(**kwargs)
773 self._x0 = xy[0]
774 self._y0 = xy[1]
775 self._width = width
776 self._height = height
777 self.angle = float(angle)
778 self.rotation_point = rotation_point
779 # Required for RectangleSelector with axes aspect ratio != 1
780 # The patch is defined in data coordinates and when changing the
781 # selector with square modifier and not in data coordinates, we need
782 # to correct for the aspect ratio difference between the data and
783 # display coordinate systems. Its value is typically provide by
784 # Axes._get_aspect_ratio()
785 self._aspect_ratio_correction = 1.0
786 self._convert_units() # Validate the inputs.
787
788 def get_path(self):
789 """Return the vertices of the rectangle."""
790 return Path.unit_rectangle()
791
792 def _convert_units(self):
793 """Convert bounds of the rectangle."""
794 x0 = self.convert_xunits(self._x0)
795 y0 = self.convert_yunits(self._y0)
796 x1 = self.convert_xunits(self._x0 + self._width)
797 y1 = self.convert_yunits(self._y0 + self._height)
798 return x0, y0, x1, y1
799
800 def get_patch_transform(self):
801 # Note: This cannot be called until after this has been added to
802 # an Axes, otherwise unit conversion will fail. This makes it very
803 # important to call the accessor method and not directly access the
804 # transformation member variable.
805 bbox = self.get_bbox()
806 if self.rotation_point == 'center':
807 width, height = bbox.x1 - bbox.x0, bbox.y1 - bbox.y0
808 rotation_point = bbox.x0 + width / 2., bbox.y0 + height / 2.
809 elif self.rotation_point == 'xy':
810 rotation_point = bbox.x0, bbox.y0
811 else:
812 rotation_point = self.rotation_point
813 return transforms.BboxTransformTo(bbox) \
814 + transforms.Affine2D() \
815 .translate(-rotation_point[0], -rotation_point[1]) \
816 .scale(1, self._aspect_ratio_correction) \
817 .rotate_deg(self.angle) \
818 .scale(1, 1 / self._aspect_ratio_correction) \
819 .translate(*rotation_point)
820
821 @property
822 def rotation_point(self):
823 """The rotation point of the patch."""
824 return self._rotation_point
825
826 @rotation_point.setter
827 def rotation_point(self, value):
828 if value in ['center', 'xy'] or (
829 isinstance(value, tuple) and len(value) == 2 and
830 isinstance(value[0], Real) and isinstance(value[1], Real)
831 ):
832 self._rotation_point = value
833 else:
834 raise ValueError("`rotation_point` must be one of "
835 "{'xy', 'center', (number, number)}.")
836
837 def get_x(self):
838 """Return the left coordinate of the rectangle."""
839 return self._x0
840
841 def get_y(self):
842 """Return the bottom coordinate of the rectangle."""
843 return self._y0
844
845 def get_xy(self):
846 """Return the left and bottom coords of the rectangle as a tuple."""
847 return self._x0, self._y0
848
849 def get_corners(self):
850 """
851 Return the corners of the rectangle, moving anti-clockwise from
852 (x0, y0).
853 """
854 return self.get_patch_transform().transform(
855 [(0, 0), (1, 0), (1, 1), (0, 1)])
856
857 def get_center(self):
858 """Return the centre of the rectangle."""
859 return self.get_patch_transform().transform((0.5, 0.5))
860
861 def get_width(self):
862 """Return the width of the rectangle."""
863 return self._width
864
865 def get_height(self):
866 """Return the height of the rectangle."""
867 return self._height
868
869 def get_angle(self):
870 """Get the rotation angle in degrees."""
871 return self.angle
872
873 def set_x(self, x):
874 """Set the left coordinate of the rectangle."""
875 self._x0 = x
876 self.stale = True
877
878 def set_y(self, y):
879 """Set the bottom coordinate of the rectangle."""
880 self._y0 = y
881 self.stale = True
882
883 def set_angle(self, angle):
884 """
885 Set the rotation angle in degrees.
886
887 The rotation is performed anti-clockwise around *xy*.
888 """
889 self.angle = angle
890 self.stale = True
891
892 def set_xy(self, xy):
893 """
894 Set the left and bottom coordinates of the rectangle.
895
896 Parameters
897 ----------
898 xy : (float, float)
899 """
900 self._x0, self._y0 = xy
901 self.stale = True
902
903 def set_width(self, w):
904 """Set the width of the rectangle."""
905 self._width = w
906 self.stale = True
907
908 def set_height(self, h):
909 """Set the height of the rectangle."""
910 self._height = h
911 self.stale = True
912
913 def set_bounds(self, *args):
914 """
915 Set the bounds of the rectangle as *left*, *bottom*, *width*, *height*.
916
917 The values may be passed as separate parameters or as a tuple::
918
919 set_bounds(left, bottom, width, height)
920 set_bounds((left, bottom, width, height))
921
922 .. ACCEPTS: (left, bottom, width, height)
923 """
924 if len(args) == 1:
925 l, b, w, h = args[0]
926 else:
927 l, b, w, h = args
928 self._x0 = l
929 self._y0 = b
930 self._width = w
931 self._height = h
932 self.stale = True
933
934 def get_bbox(self):
935 """Return the `.Bbox`."""
936 return transforms.Bbox.from_extents(*self._convert_units())
937
938 xy = property(get_xy, set_xy)

941class RegularPolygon(Patch):

946 return s % (self.xy[0], self.xy[1], self.numvertices, self.radius,
947 self.orientation)

951 radius=5, orientation=0, **kwargs):

956 The center position.
957
958 numVertices : int
959 The number of vertices.
960
961 radius : float

984 return self._patch_transform.clear() \
985 .scale(self.radius) \
986 .rotate(self.orientation) \
987 .translate(*self.xy)

1018class StepPatch(PathPatch):
1019 """
1020 A path patch describing a stepwise constant function.
1021
1022 By default, the path is not closed and starts and stops at
1023 baseline value.
1024 """
1025
1026 _edge_default = False
1027
1028 @_docstring.interpd
1029 def __init__(self, values, edges, *,
1030 orientation='vertical', baseline=0, **kwargs):
1031 """
1032 Parameters
1033 ----------
1034 values : array-like
1035 The step heights.
1036
1037 edges : array-like
1038 The edge positions, with ``len(edges) == len(vals) + 1``,
1039 between which the curve takes on vals values.
1040
1041 orientation : {'vertical', 'horizontal'}, default: 'vertical'
1042 The direction of the steps. Vertical means that *values* are
1043 along the y-axis, and edges are along the x-axis.
1044
1045 baseline : float, array-like or None, default: 0
1046 The bottom value of the bounding edges or when
1047 ``fill=True``, position of lower edge. If *fill* is
1048 True or an array is passed to *baseline*, a closed
1049 path is drawn.
1050
1051 **kwargs
1052 `Patch` properties:
1053
1054 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
1055 """
1056 self.orientation = orientation
1057 self._edges = np.asarray(edges)
1058 self._values = np.asarray(values)
1059 self._baseline = np.asarray(baseline) if baseline is not None else None
1060 self._update_path()
1061 super().__init__(self._path, **kwargs)
1062
1063 def _update_path(self):
1064 if np.isnan(np.sum(self._edges)):
1065 raise ValueError('Nan values in "edges" are disallowed')
1066 if self._edges.size - 1 != self._values.size:
1067 raise ValueError('Size mismatch between "values" and "edges". '
1068 "Expected `len(values) + 1 == len(edges)`, but "
1069 f"`len(values) = {self._values.size}` and "
1070 f"`len(edges) = {self._edges.size}`.")
1071 # Initializing with empty arrays allows supporting empty stairs.
1072 verts, codes = [np.empty((0, 2))], [np.empty(0, dtype=Path.code_type)]
1073
1074 _nan_mask = np.isnan(self._values)
1075 if self._baseline is not None:
1076 _nan_mask |= np.isnan(self._baseline)
1077 for idx0, idx1 in cbook.contiguous_regions(~_nan_mask):
1078 x = np.repeat(self._edges[idx0:idx1+1], 2)
1079 y = np.repeat(self._values[idx0:idx1], 2)
1080 if self._baseline is None:
1081 y = np.concatenate([y[:1], y, y[-1:]])
1082 elif self._baseline.ndim == 0: # single baseline value
1083 y = np.concatenate([[self._baseline], y, [self._baseline]])
1084 elif self._baseline.ndim == 1: # baseline array
1085 base = np.repeat(self._baseline[idx0:idx1], 2)[::-1]
1086 x = np.concatenate([x, x[::-1]])
1087 y = np.concatenate([base[-1:], y, base[:1],
1088 base[:1], base, base[-1:]])
1089 else: # no baseline
1090 raise ValueError('Invalid `baseline` specified')
1091 if self.orientation == 'vertical':
1092 xy = np.column_stack([x, y])
1093 else:
1094 xy = np.column_stack([y, x])
1095 verts.append(xy)
1096 codes.append([Path.MOVETO] + [Path.LINETO]*(len(xy)-1))
1097 self._path = Path(np.concatenate(verts), np.concatenate(codes))
1098
1099 def get_data(self):
1100 """Get `.StepPatch` values, edges and baseline as namedtuple."""
1101 StairData = namedtuple('StairData', 'values edges baseline')
1102 return StairData(self._values, self._edges, self._baseline)
1103
1104 def set_data(self, values=None, edges=None, baseline=None):
1105 """
1106 Set `.StepPatch` values, edges and baseline.
1107
1108 Parameters
1109 ----------
1110 values : 1D array-like or None
1111 Will not update values, if passing None
1112 edges : 1D array-like, optional
1113 baseline : float, 1D array-like or None
1114 """
1115 if values is None and edges is None and baseline is None:
1116 raise ValueError("Must set *values*, *edges* or *baseline*.")
1117 if values is not None:
1118 self._values = np.asarray(values)
1119 if edges is not None:
1120 self._edges = np.asarray(edges)
1121 if baseline is not None:
1122 self._baseline = np.asarray(baseline)
1123 self._update_path()
1124 self.stale = True
1125
1126
1127class Polygon(Patch):
1128 """A general polygon patch."""
1129
1130 def __str__(self):
1131 if len(self._path.vertices):
1132 s = "Polygon%d((%g, %g) ...)"
1133 return s % (len(self._path.vertices), *self._path.vertices[0])
1134 else:
1135 return "Polygon0()"
1136
1137 @_docstring.interpd
1138 def __init__(self, xy, *, closed=True, **kwargs):
1139 """
1140 Parameters
1141 ----------
1142 xy : (N, 2) array
1143
1144 closed : bool, default: True
1145 Whether the polygon is closed (i.e., has identical start and end
1146 points).
1147
1148 **kwargs
1149 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
1150 """
1151 super().__init__(**kwargs)
1152 self._closed = closed
1153 self.set_xy(xy)
1154
1155 def get_path(self):
1156 """Get the `.Path` of the polygon."""
1157 return self._path
1158
1159 def get_closed(self):
1160 """Return whether the polygon is closed."""
1161 return self._closed
1162
1163 def set_closed(self, closed):
1164 """
1165 Set whether the polygon is closed.
1166
1167 Parameters
1168 ----------
1169 closed : bool
1170 True if the polygon is closed
1171 """
1172 if self._closed == bool(closed):
1173 return
1174 self._closed = bool(closed)
1175 self.set_xy(self.get_xy())
1176 self.stale = True
1177
1178 def get_xy(self):
1179 """
1180 Get the vertices of the path.
1181
1182 Returns
1183 -------
1184 (N, 2) array
1185 The coordinates of the vertices.
1186 """
1187 return self._path.vertices
1188
1189 def set_xy(self, xy):
1190 """
1191 Set the vertices of the polygon.
1192
1193 Parameters
1194 ----------
1195 xy : (N, 2) array-like
1196 The coordinates of the vertices.
1197
1198 Notes
1199 -----
1200 Unlike `.Path`, we do not ignore the last input vertex. If the
1201 polygon is meant to be closed, and the last point of the polygon is not
1202 equal to the first, we assume that the user has not explicitly passed a
1203 ``CLOSEPOLY`` vertex, and add it ourselves.
1204 """
1205 xy = np.asarray(xy)
1206 nverts, _ = xy.shape
1207 if self._closed:
1208 # if the first and last vertex are the "same", then we assume that
1209 # the user explicitly passed the CLOSEPOLY vertex. Otherwise, we
1210 # have to append one since the last vertex will be "ignored" by
1211 # Path
1212 if nverts == 1 or nverts > 1 and (xy[0] != xy[-1]).any():
1213 xy = np.concatenate([xy, [xy[0]]])
1214 else:
1215 # if we aren't closed, and the last vertex matches the first, then
1216 # we assume we have an unnecessary CLOSEPOLY vertex and remove it
1217 if nverts > 2 and (xy[0] == xy[-1]).all():
1218 xy = xy[:-1]
1219 self._path = Path(xy, closed=self._closed)
1220 self.stale = True
1221
1222 xy = property(get_xy, set_xy,
1223 doc='The vertices of the path as a (N, 2) array.')
1224
1225
1226class Wedge(Patch):
1227 """Wedge shaped patch."""
1228
1229 def __str__(self):
1230 pars = (self.center[0], self.center[1], self.r,
1231 self.theta1, self.theta2, self.width)
1232 fmt = "Wedge(center=(%g, %g), r=%g, theta1=%g, theta2=%g, width=%s)"
1233 return fmt % pars
1234
1235 @_docstring.interpd
1236 def __init__(self, center, r, theta1, theta2, *, width=None, **kwargs):
1237 """
1238 A wedge centered at *x*, *y* center with radius *r* that
1239 sweeps *theta1* to *theta2* (in degrees). If *width* is given,
1240 then a partial wedge is drawn from inner radius *r* - *width*
1241 to outer radius *r*.
1242
1243 Valid keyword arguments are:
1244
1245 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
1246 """
1247 super().__init__(**kwargs)
1248 self.center = center
1249 self.r, self.width = r, width
1250 self.theta1, self.theta2 = theta1, theta2
1251 self._patch_transform = transforms.IdentityTransform()
1252 self._recompute_path()
1253
1254 def _recompute_path(self):
1255 # Inner and outer rings are connected unless the annulus is complete
1256 if abs((self.theta2 - self.theta1) - 360) <= 1e-12:
1257 theta1, theta2 = 0, 360
1258 connector = Path.MOVETO
1259 else:
1260 theta1, theta2 = self.theta1, self.theta2
1261 connector = Path.LINETO
1262
1263 # Form the outer ring
1264 arc = Path.arc(theta1, theta2)
1265
1266 if self.width is not None:
1267 # Partial annulus needs to draw the outer ring
1268 # followed by a reversed and scaled inner ring
1269 v1 = arc.vertices
1270 v2 = arc.vertices[::-1] * (self.r - self.width) / self.r
1271 v = np.concatenate([v1, v2, [(0, 0)]])
1272 c = [*arc.codes, connector, *arc.codes[1:], Path.CLOSEPOLY]
1273 else:
1274 # Wedge doesn't need an inner ring
1275 v = np.concatenate([arc.vertices, [(0, 0), (0, 0)]])
1276 c = [*arc.codes, connector, Path.CLOSEPOLY]
1277
1278 # Shift and scale the wedge to the final location.
1279 self._path = Path(v * self.r + self.center, c)
1280
1281 def set_center(self, center):
1282 self._path = None
1283 self.center = center
1284 self.stale = True
1285
1286 def set_radius(self, radius):
1287 self._path = None
1288 self.r = radius
1289 self.stale = True
1290
1291 def set_theta1(self, theta1):
1292 self._path = None
1293 self.theta1 = theta1
1294 self.stale = True
1295
1296 def set_theta2(self, theta2):
1297 self._path = None
1298 self.theta2 = theta2
1299 self.stale = True
1300
1301 def set_width(self, width):
1302 self._path = None
1303 self.width = width
1304 self.stale = True
1305
1306 def get_path(self):
1307 if self._path is None:
1308 self._recompute_path()
1309 return self._path
1310

1312# COVERAGE NOTE: Not used internally or from examples
1313class Arrow(Patch):
1314 """An arrow patch."""
1315
1316 def __str__(self):
1317 return "Arrow()"
1318
1319 _path = Path._create_closed([
1320 [0.0, 0.1], [0.0, -0.1], [0.8, -0.1], [0.8, -0.3], [1.0, 0.0],
1321 [0.8, 0.3], [0.8, 0.1]])
1322
1323 @_docstring.interpd
1324 def __init__(self, x, y, dx, dy, *, width=1.0, **kwargs):
1325 """
1326 Draws an arrow from (*x*, *y*) to (*x* + *dx*, *y* + *dy*).
1327 The width of the arrow is scaled by *width*.
1328
1329 Parameters
1330 ----------
1331 x : float
1332 x coordinate of the arrow tail.
1333 y : float
1334 y coordinate of the arrow tail.
1335 dx : float
1336 Arrow length in the x direction.
1337 dy : float
1338 Arrow length in the y direction.
1339 width : float, default: 1
1340 Scale factor for the width of the arrow. With a default value of 1,
1341 the tail width is 0.2 and head width is 0.6.
1342 **kwargs
1343 Keyword arguments control the `Patch` properties:
1344
1345 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
1346
1347 See Also
1348 --------
1349 FancyArrow
1350 Patch that allows independent control of the head and tail
1351 properties.
1352 """
1353 super().__init__(**kwargs)
1354 self.set_data(x, y, dx, dy, width)
1355
1356 def get_path(self):
1357 return self._path
1358
1359 def get_patch_transform(self):
1360 return self._patch_transform
1361
1362 def set_data(self, x=None, y=None, dx=None, dy=None, width=None):
1363 """
1364 Set `.Arrow` x, y, dx, dy and width.
1365 Values left as None will not be updated.
1366
1367 Parameters
1368 ----------
1369 x, y : float or None, default: None
1370 The x and y coordinates of the arrow base.
1371
1372 dx, dy : float or None, default: None
1373 The length of the arrow along x and y direction.
1374
1375 width : float or None, default: None
1376 Width of full arrow tail.
1377 """
1378 if x is not None:
1379 self._x = x
1380 if y is not None:
1381 self._y = y
1382 if dx is not None:
1383 self._dx = dx
1384 if dy is not None:
1385 self._dy = dy
1386 if width is not None:
1387 self._width = width
1388 self._patch_transform = (
1389 transforms.Affine2D()
1390 .scale(np.hypot(self._dx, self._dy), self._width)
1391 .rotate(np.arctan2(self._dy, self._dx))
1392 .translate(self._x, self._y)
1393 .frozen())

1396class FancyArrow(Polygon):
1397 """
1398 Like Arrow, but lets you set head width and head height independently.
1399 """
1400
1401 _edge_default = True
1402
1403 def __str__(self):
1404 return "FancyArrow()"
1405
1406 @_docstring.interpd
1407 def __init__(self, x, y, dx, dy, *,
1408 width=0.001, length_includes_head=False, head_width=None,
1409 head_length=None, shape='full', overhang=0,
1410 head_starts_at_zero=False, **kwargs):
1411 """
1412 Parameters
1413 ----------
1414 x, y : float
1415 The x and y coordinates of the arrow base.
1416
1417 dx, dy : float
1418 The length of the arrow along x and y direction.
1419
1420 width : float, default: 0.001
1421 Width of full arrow tail.
1422
1423 length_includes_head : bool, default: False
1424 True if head is to be counted in calculating the length.
1425
1426 head_width : float or None, default: 3*width
1427 Total width of the full arrow head.
1428
1429 head_length : float or None, default: 1.5*head_width
1430 Length of arrow head.
1431
1432 shape : {'full', 'left', 'right'}, default: 'full'
1433 Draw the left-half, right-half, or full arrow.
1434
1435 overhang : float, default: 0
1436 Fraction that the arrow is swept back (0 overhang means
1437 triangular shape). Can be negative or greater than one.
1438
1439 head_starts_at_zero : bool, default: False
1440 If True, the head starts being drawn at coordinate 0
1441 instead of ending at coordinate 0.
1442
1443 **kwargs
1444 `.Patch` properties:
1445
1446 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
1447 """
1448 self._x = x
1449 self._y = y
1450 self._dx = dx
1451 self._dy = dy
1452 self._width = width
1453 self._length_includes_head = length_includes_head
1454 self._head_width = head_width
1455 self._head_length = head_length
1456 self._shape = shape
1457 self._overhang = overhang
1458 self._head_starts_at_zero = head_starts_at_zero
1459 self._make_verts()
1460 super().__init__(self.verts, closed=True, **kwargs)
1461
1462 def set_data(self, *, x=None, y=None, dx=None, dy=None, width=None,
1463 head_width=None, head_length=None):
1464 """
1465 Set `.FancyArrow` x, y, dx, dy, width, head_with, and head_length.
1466 Values left as None will not be updated.
1467
1468 Parameters
1469 ----------
1470 x, y : float or None, default: None
1471 The x and y coordinates of the arrow base.
1472
1473 dx, dy : float or None, default: None
1474 The length of the arrow along x and y direction.
1475
1476 width : float or None, default: None
1477 Width of full arrow tail.
1478
1479 head_width : float or None, default: None
1480 Total width of the full arrow head.
1481
1482 head_length : float or None, default: None
1483 Length of arrow head.
1484 """
1485 if x is not None:
1486 self._x = x
1487 if y is not None:
1488 self._y = y
1489 if dx is not None:
1490 self._dx = dx
1491 if dy is not None:
1492 self._dy = dy
1493 if width is not None:
1494 self._width = width
1495 if head_width is not None:
1496 self._head_width = head_width
1497 if head_length is not None:
1498 self._head_length = head_length
1499 self._make_verts()
1500 self.set_xy(self.verts)
1501
1502 def _make_verts(self):
1503 if self._head_width is None:
1504 head_width = 3 * self._width
1505 else:
1506 head_width = self._head_width
1507 if self._head_length is None:
1508 head_length = 1.5 * head_width
1509 else:
1510 head_length = self._head_length
1511
1512 distance = np.hypot(self._dx, self._dy)
1513
1514 if self._length_includes_head:
1515 length = distance
1516 else:
1517 length = distance + head_length
1518 if not length:
1519 self.verts = np.empty([0, 2]) # display nothing if empty
1520 else:
1521 # start by drawing horizontal arrow, point at (0, 0)
1522 hw, hl = head_width, head_length
1523 hs, lw = self._overhang, self._width
1524 left_half_arrow = np.array([
1525 [0.0, 0.0], # tip
1526 [-hl, -hw / 2], # leftmost
1527 [-hl * (1 - hs), -lw / 2], # meets stem
1528 [-length, -lw / 2], # bottom left
1529 [-length, 0],
1530 ])
1531 # if we're not including the head, shift up by head length
1532 if not self._length_includes_head:
1533 left_half_arrow += [head_length, 0]
1534 # if the head starts at 0, shift up by another head length
1535 if self._head_starts_at_zero:
1536 left_half_arrow += [head_length / 2, 0]
1537 # figure out the shape, and complete accordingly
1538 if self._shape == 'left':
1539 coords = left_half_arrow
1540 else:
1541 right_half_arrow = left_half_arrow * [1, -1]
1542 if self._shape == 'right':
1543 coords = right_half_arrow
1544 elif self._shape == 'full':
1545 # The half-arrows contain the midpoint of the stem,
1546 # which we can omit from the full arrow. Including it
1547 # twice caused a problem with xpdf.
1548 coords = np.concatenate([left_half_arrow[:-1],
1549 right_half_arrow[-2::-1]])
1550 else:
1551 raise ValueError(f"Got unknown shape: {self._shape!r}")
1552 if distance != 0:
1553 cx = self._dx / distance
1554 sx = self._dy / distance
1555 else:
1556 # Account for division by zero
1557 cx, sx = 0, 1
1558 M = [[cx, sx], [-sx, cx]]
1559 self.verts = np.dot(coords, M) + [
1560 self._x + self._dx,
1561 self._y + self._dy,
1562 ]
1563
1564
1565_docstring.interpd.register(
1566 FancyArrow="\n".join(
1567 (inspect.getdoc(FancyArrow.__init__) or "").splitlines()[2:]))

1595class Ellipse(Patch):

1600 self.width, self.height, self.angle)
1601 fmt = "Ellipse(xy=(%s, %s), width=%s, height=%s, angle=%s)"
1602 return fmt % pars

1604 @_docstring.interpd
1605 def __init__(self, xy, width, height, *, angle=0, **kwargs):
1606 """
1607 Parameters
1608 ----------
1609 xy : (float, float)
1610 xy coordinates of ellipse centre.
1611 width : float
1612 Total length (diameter) of horizontal axis.
1613 height : float
1614 Total length (diameter) of vertical axis.

1616 Rotation in degrees anti-clockwise.

1618 Notes

1621

1625
1626 self._center = xy
1627 self._width, self._height = width, height
1628 self._angle = angle
1629 self._path = Path.unit_circle()
1630 # Required for EllipseSelector with axes aspect ratio != 1
1631 # The patch is defined in data coordinates and when changing the
1632 # selector with square modifier and not in data coordinates, we need
1633 # to correct for the aspect ratio difference between the data and
1634 # display coordinate systems.
1635 self._aspect_ratio_correction = 1.0
1636 # Note: This cannot be calculated until this is added to an Axes
1637 self._patch_transform = transforms.IdentityTransform()
1638
1639 def _recompute_transform(self):
1640 """
1641 Notes
1642 -----
1643 This cannot be called until after this has been added to an Axes,
1644 otherwise unit conversion will fail. This makes it very important to
1645 call the accessor method and not directly access the transformation
1646 member variable.
1647 """
1648 center = (self.convert_xunits(self._center[0]),
1649 self.convert_yunits(self._center[1]))
1650 width = self.convert_xunits(self._width)
1651 height = self.convert_yunits(self._height)
1652 self._patch_transform = transforms.Affine2D() \
1653 .scale(width * 0.5, height * 0.5 * self._aspect_ratio_correction) \
1654 .rotate_deg(self.angle) \
1655 .scale(1, 1 / self._aspect_ratio_correction) \
1656 .translate(*center)
1657

1660 return self._path

1663 self._recompute_transform()
1664 return self._patch_transform

1675 self.stale = True

1679 return self._center

1739
1740 The bounding box orientation is moving anti-clockwise from the

1742 """
1743 return self.get_patch_transform().transform(
1744 [(-1, -1), (1, -1), (1, 1), (-1, 1)])

1746 def get_vertices(self):
1747 """
1748 Return the vertices coordinates of the ellipse.
1749
1750 The definition can be found `here <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ellipse>`_
1751
1752 .. versionadded:: 3.8
1753 """
1754 if self.width < self.height:
1755 ret = self.get_patch_transform().transform([(0, 1), (0, -1)])
1756 else:
1757 ret = self.get_patch_transform().transform([(1, 0), (-1, 0)])
1758 return [tuple(x) for x in ret]
1759
1760 def get_co_vertices(self):
1761 """
1762 Return the co-vertices coordinates of the ellipse.
1763
1764 The definition can be found `here <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ellipse>`_
1765
1766 .. versionadded:: 3.8
1767 """
1768 if self.width < self.height:
1769 ret = self.get_patch_transform().transform([(1, 0), (-1, 0)])
1770 else:
1771 ret = self.get_patch_transform().transform([(0, 1), (0, -1)])
1772 return [tuple(x) for x in ret]

1775class Annulus(Patch):

1784 ----------

1787 r : float or (float, float)
1788 The radius, or semi-axes:
1789

1791 - If two floats: semi-major and -minor axes of outer ellipse.
1792 width : float
1793 Width (thickness) of the annular ring. The width is measured inward
1794 from the outer ellipse so that for the inner ellipse the semi-axes
1795 are given by ``r - width``. *width* must be less than or equal to
1796 the semi-minor axis.

1799 x-axis). Ignored for circular annuli (i.e., if *r* is a scalar).
1800 **kwargs

1802

1804 """

1810 self.angle = angle
1811 self._path = None

1814 if self.a == self.b:
1815 r = self.a
1816 else:
1817 r = (self.a, self.b)
1818
1819 return "Annulus(xy=(%s, %s), r=%s, width=%s, angle=%s)" % \
1820 (*self.center, r, self.width, self.angle)

1906 def set_radii(self, r):
1907 """
1908 Set the semi-major (*a*) and semi-minor radii (*b*) of the annulus.
1909
1910 Parameters
1911 ----------
1912 r : float or (float, float)
1913 The radius, or semi-axes:
1914
1915 - If float: radius of the outer circle.
1916 - If two floats: semi-major and -minor axes of outer ellipse.
1917 """
1918 if np.shape(r) == (2,):
1919 self.a, self.b = r
1920 elif np.shape(r) == ():
1921 self.a = self.b = float(r)
1922 else:
1923 raise ValueError("Parameter 'r' must be one or two floats.")
1924
1925 self._path = None
1926 self.stale = True
1927
1928 def get_radii(self):
1929 """Return the semi-major and semi-minor radii of the annulus."""
1930 return self.a, self.b
1931
1932 radii = property(get_radii, set_radii)
1933
1934 def _transform_verts(self, verts, a, b):
1935 return transforms.Affine2D() \
1936 .scale(*self._convert_xy_units((a, b))) \
1937 .rotate_deg(self.angle) \
1938 .translate(*self._convert_xy_units(self.center)) \
1939 .transform(verts)
1940
1941 def _recompute_path(self):
1942 # circular arc
1943 arc = Path.arc(0, 360)
1944
1945 # annulus needs to draw an outer ring
1946 # followed by a reversed and scaled inner ring
1947 a, b, w = self.a, self.b, self.width
1948 v1 = self._transform_verts(arc.vertices, a, b)
1949 v2 = self._transform_verts(arc.vertices[::-1], a - w, b - w)
1950 v = np.vstack([v1, v2, v1[0, :], (0, 0)])
1951 c = np.hstack([arc.codes, Path.MOVETO,
1952 arc.codes[1:], Path.MOVETO,
1953 Path.CLOSEPOLY])
1954 self._path = Path(v, c)
1955
1956 def get_path(self):
1957 if self._path is None:
1958 self._recompute_path()
1959 return self._path

1974 Create a true circle at center *xy* = (*x*, *y*) with given *radius*.

1977 Bezier splines and is much closer to a scale-free circle.

2004class Arc(Ellipse):
2005 """
2006 An elliptical arc, i.e. a segment of an ellipse.
2007
2008 Due to internal optimizations, the arc cannot be filled.
2009 """
2010
2011 def __str__(self):
2012 pars = (self.center[0], self.center[1], self.width,
2013 self.height, self.angle, self.theta1, self.theta2)
2014 fmt = ("Arc(xy=(%g, %g), width=%g, "
2015 "height=%g, angle=%g, theta1=%g, theta2=%g)")
2016 return fmt % pars
2017
2018 @_docstring.interpd
2019 def __init__(self, xy, width, height, *,
2020 angle=0.0, theta1=0.0, theta2=360.0, **kwargs):
2021 """
2022 Parameters
2023 ----------
2024 xy : (float, float)
2025 The center of the ellipse.
2026
2027 width : float
2028 The length of the horizontal axis.
2029
2030 height : float
2031 The length of the vertical axis.
2032
2033 angle : float
2034 Rotation of the ellipse in degrees (counterclockwise).
2035
2036 theta1, theta2 : float, default: 0, 360
2037 Starting and ending angles of the arc in degrees. These values
2038 are relative to *angle*, e.g. if *angle* = 45 and *theta1* = 90
2039 the absolute starting angle is 135.
2040 Default *theta1* = 0, *theta2* = 360, i.e. a complete ellipse.
2041 The arc is drawn in the counterclockwise direction.
2042 Angles greater than or equal to 360, or smaller than 0, are
2043 represented by an equivalent angle in the range [0, 360), by
2044 taking the input value mod 360.
2045
2046 Other Parameters
2047 ----------------
2048 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Patch` properties
2049 Most `.Patch` properties are supported as keyword arguments,
2050 except *fill* and *facecolor* because filling is not supported.
2051
2052 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
2053 """
2054 fill = kwargs.setdefault('fill', False)
2055 if fill:
2056 raise ValueError("Arc objects cannot be filled")
2057
2058 super().__init__(xy, width, height, angle=angle, **kwargs)
2059
2060 self.theta1 = theta1
2061 self.theta2 = theta2
2062 (self._theta1, self._theta2, self._stretched_width,
2063 self._stretched_height) = self._theta_stretch()
2064 self._path = Path.arc(self._theta1, self._theta2)
2065
2066 @artist.allow_rasterization
2067 def draw(self, renderer):
2068 """
2069 Draw the arc to the given *renderer*.
2070
2071 Notes
2072 -----
2073 Ellipses are normally drawn using an approximation that uses
2074 eight cubic Bezier splines. The error of this approximation
2075 is 1.89818e-6, according to this unverified source:
2076
2077 Lancaster, Don. *Approximating a Circle or an Ellipse Using
2078 Four Bezier Cubic Splines.*
2079
2080 https://www.tinaja.com/glib/ellipse4.pdf
2081
2082 There is a use case where very large ellipses must be drawn
2083 with very high accuracy, and it is too expensive to render the
2084 entire ellipse with enough segments (either splines or line
2085 segments). Therefore, in the case where either radius of the
2086 ellipse is large enough that the error of the spline
2087 approximation will be visible (greater than one pixel offset
2088 from the ideal), a different technique is used.
2089
2090 In that case, only the visible parts of the ellipse are drawn,
2091 with each visible arc using a fixed number of spline segments
2092 (8). The algorithm proceeds as follows:
2093
2094 1. The points where the ellipse intersects the axes (or figure)
2095 bounding box are located. (This is done by performing an inverse
2096 transformation on the bbox such that it is relative to the unit
2097 circle -- this makes the intersection calculation much easier than
2098 doing rotated ellipse intersection directly.)
2099
2100 This uses the "line intersecting a circle" algorithm from:
2101
2102 Vince, John. *Geometry for Computer Graphics: Formulae,
2103 Examples & Proofs.* London: Springer-Verlag, 2005.
2104
2105 2. The angles of each of the intersection points are calculated.
2106
2107 3. Proceeding counterclockwise starting in the positive
2108 x-direction, each of the visible arc-segments between the
2109 pairs of vertices are drawn using the Bezier arc
2110 approximation technique implemented in `.Path.arc`.
2111 """
2112 if not self.get_visible():
2113 return
2114
2115 self._recompute_transform()
2116
2117 self._update_path()
2118 # Get width and height in pixels we need to use
2119 # `self.get_data_transform` rather than `self.get_transform`
2120 # because we want the transform from dataspace to the
2121 # screen space to estimate how big the arc will be in physical
2122 # units when rendered (the transform that we get via
2123 # `self.get_transform()` goes from an idealized unit-radius
2124 # space to screen space).
2125 data_to_screen_trans = self.get_data_transform()
2126 pwidth, pheight = (
2127 data_to_screen_trans.transform((self._stretched_width,
2128 self._stretched_height)) -
2129 data_to_screen_trans.transform((0, 0)))
2130 inv_error = (1.0 / 1.89818e-6) * 0.5
2131
2132 if pwidth < inv_error and pheight < inv_error:
2133 return Patch.draw(self, renderer)
2134
2135 def line_circle_intersect(x0, y0, x1, y1):
2136 dx = x1 - x0
2137 dy = y1 - y0
2138 dr2 = dx * dx + dy * dy
2139 D = x0 * y1 - x1 * y0
2140 D2 = D * D
2141 discrim = dr2 - D2
2142 if discrim >= 0.0:
2143 sign_dy = np.copysign(1, dy) # +/-1, never 0.
2144 sqrt_discrim = np.sqrt(discrim)
2145 return np.array(
2146 [[(D * dy + sign_dy * dx * sqrt_discrim) / dr2,
2147 (-D * dx + abs(dy) * sqrt_discrim) / dr2],
2148 [(D * dy - sign_dy * dx * sqrt_discrim) / dr2,
2149 (-D * dx - abs(dy) * sqrt_discrim) / dr2]])
2150 else:
2151 return np.empty((0, 2))
2152
2153 def segment_circle_intersect(x0, y0, x1, y1):
2154 epsilon = 1e-9
2155 if x1 < x0:
2156 x0e, x1e = x1, x0
2157 else:
2158 x0e, x1e = x0, x1
2159 if y1 < y0:
2160 y0e, y1e = y1, y0
2161 else:
2162 y0e, y1e = y0, y1
2163 xys = line_circle_intersect(x0, y0, x1, y1)
2164 xs, ys = xys.T
2165 return xys[
2166 (x0e - epsilon < xs) & (xs < x1e + epsilon)
2167 & (y0e - epsilon < ys) & (ys < y1e + epsilon)
2168 ]
2169
2170 # Transform the Axes (or figure) box_path so that it is relative to
2171 # the unit circle in the same way that it is relative to the desired
2172 # ellipse.
2173 box_path_transform = (
2174 transforms.BboxTransformTo((self.axes or self.get_figure(root=False)).bbox)
2175 - self.get_transform())
2176 box_path = Path.unit_rectangle().transformed(box_path_transform)
2177
2178 thetas = set()
2179 # For each of the point pairs, there is a line segment
2180 for p0, p1 in zip(box_path.vertices[:-1], box_path.vertices[1:]):
2181 xy = segment_circle_intersect(*p0, *p1)
2182 x, y = xy.T
2183 # arctan2 return [-pi, pi), the rest of our angles are in
2184 # [0, 360], adjust as needed.
2185 theta = (np.rad2deg(np.arctan2(y, x)) + 360) % 360
2186 thetas.update(
2187 theta[(self._theta1 < theta) & (theta < self._theta2)])
2188 thetas = sorted(thetas) + [self._theta2]
2189 last_theta = self._theta1
2190 theta1_rad = np.deg2rad(self._theta1)
2191 inside = box_path.contains_point(
2192 (np.cos(theta1_rad), np.sin(theta1_rad))
2193 )
2194
2195 # save original path
2196 path_original = self._path
2197 for theta in thetas:
2198 if inside:
2199 self._path = Path.arc(last_theta, theta, 8)
2200 Patch.draw(self, renderer)
2201 inside = False
2202 else:
2203 inside = True
2204 last_theta = theta
2205
2206 # restore original path
2207 self._path = path_original
2208
2209 def _update_path(self):
2210 # Compute new values and update and set new _path if any value changed
2211 stretched = self._theta_stretch()
2212 if any(a != b for a, b in zip(
2213 stretched, (self._theta1, self._theta2, self._stretched_width,
2214 self._stretched_height))):
2215 (self._theta1, self._theta2, self._stretched_width,
2216 self._stretched_height) = stretched
2217 self._path = Path.arc(self._theta1, self._theta2)
2218
2219 def _theta_stretch(self):
2220 # If the width and height of ellipse are not equal, take into account
2221 # stretching when calculating angles to draw between
2222 def theta_stretch(theta, scale):
2223 theta = np.deg2rad(theta)
2224 x = np.cos(theta)
2225 y = np.sin(theta)
2226 stheta = np.rad2deg(np.arctan2(scale * y, x))
2227 # arctan2 has the range [-pi, pi], we expect [0, 2*pi]
2228 return (stheta + 360) % 360
2229
2230 width = self.convert_xunits(self.width)
2231 height = self.convert_yunits(self.height)
2232 if (
2233 # if we need to stretch the angles because we are distorted
2234 width != height
2235 # and we are not doing a full circle.
2236 #
2237 # 0 and 360 do not exactly round-trip through the angle
2238 # stretching (due to both float precision limitations and
2239 # the difference between the range of arctan2 [-pi, pi] and
2240 # this method [0, 360]) so avoid doing it if we don't have to.
2241 and not (self.theta1 != self.theta2 and
2242 self.theta1 % 360 == self.theta2 % 360)
2243 ):
2244 theta1 = theta_stretch(self.theta1, width / height)
2245 theta2 = theta_stretch(self.theta2, width / height)
2246 return theta1, theta2, width, height
2247 return self.theta1, self.theta2, width, height
2248
2249
2250def bbox_artist(artist, renderer, props=None, fill=True):
2251 """
2252 A debug function to draw a rectangle around the bounding
2253 box returned by an artist's `.Artist.get_window_extent`
2254 to test whether the artist is returning the correct bbox.
2255
2256 *props* is a dict of rectangle props with the additional property
2257 'pad' that sets the padding around the bbox in points.
2258 """
2259 if props is None:
2260 props = {}
2261 props = props.copy() # don't want to alter the pad externally
2262 pad = props.pop('pad', 4)
2263 pad = renderer.points_to_pixels(pad)
2264 bbox = artist.get_window_extent(renderer)
2265 r = Rectangle(
2266 xy=(bbox.x0 - pad / 2, bbox.y0 - pad / 2),
2267 width=bbox.width + pad, height=bbox.height + pad,
2268 fill=fill, transform=transforms.IdentityTransform(), clip_on=False)
2269 r.update(props)
2270 r.draw(renderer)
2271
2272
2273def draw_bbox(bbox, renderer, color='k', trans=None):
2274 """
2275 A debug function to draw a rectangle around the bounding
2276 box returned by an artist's `.Artist.get_window_extent`
2277 to test whether the artist is returning the correct bbox.
2278 """
2279 r = Rectangle(xy=bbox.p0, width=bbox.width, height=bbox.height,
2280 edgecolor=color, fill=False, clip_on=False)
2281 if trans is not None:
2282 r.set_transform(trans)
2283 r.draw(renderer)

2286class _Style:
2287 """
2288 A base class for the Styles. It is meant to be a container class,
2289 where actual styles are declared as subclass of it, and it
2290 provides some helper functions.
2291 """
2292
2293 def __init_subclass__(cls):
2294 # Automatically perform docstring interpolation on the subclasses:
2295 # This allows listing the supported styles via
2296 # - %(BoxStyle:table)s
2297 # - %(ConnectionStyle:table)s
2298 # - %(ArrowStyle:table)s
2299 # and additionally adding .. ACCEPTS: blocks via
2300 # - %(BoxStyle:table_and_accepts)s
2301 # - %(ConnectionStyle:table_and_accepts)s
2302 # - %(ArrowStyle:table_and_accepts)s
2303 _docstring.interpd.register(**{
2304 f"{cls.__name__}:table": cls.pprint_styles(),
2305 f"{cls.__name__}:table_and_accepts": (
2306 cls.pprint_styles()
2307 + "\n\n .. ACCEPTS: ["
2308 + "|".join(map(" '{}' ".format, cls._style_list))
2309 + "]")
2310 })
2311
2312 def __new__(cls, stylename, **kwargs):
2313 """Return the instance of the subclass with the given style name."""
2314 # The "class" should have the _style_list attribute, which is a mapping
2315 # of style names to style classes.
2316 _list = stylename.replace(" ", "").split(",")
2317 _name = _list[0].lower()
2318 try:
2319 _cls = cls._style_list[_name]
2320 except KeyError as err:
2321 raise ValueError(f"Unknown style: {stylename!r}") from err
2322 try:
2323 _args_pair = [cs.split("=") for cs in _list[1:]]
2324 _args = {k: float(v) for k, v in _args_pair}
2325 except ValueError as err:
2326 raise ValueError(
2327 f"Incorrect style argument: {stylename!r}") from err
2328 return _cls(**{**_args, **kwargs})
2329
2330 @classmethod
2331 def get_styles(cls):
2332 """Return a dictionary of available styles."""
2333 return cls._style_list
2334
2335 @classmethod
2336 def pprint_styles(cls):
2337 """Return the available styles as pretty-printed string."""
2338 table = [('Class', 'Name', 'Parameters'),
2339 *[(cls.__name__,
2340 # Add backquotes, as - and | have special meaning in reST.
2341 f'``{name}``',
2342 # [1:-1] drops the surrounding parentheses.
2343 str(inspect.signature(cls))[1:-1] or 'None')
2344 for name, cls in cls._style_list.items()]]
2345 # Convert to rst table.
2346 col_len = [max(len(cell) for cell in column) for column in zip(*table)]
2347 table_formatstr = ' '.join('=' * cl for cl in col_len)
2348 rst_table = '\n'.join([
2349 '',
2350 table_formatstr,
2351 ' '.join(cell.ljust(cl) for cell, cl in zip(table[0], col_len)),
2352 table_formatstr,
2353 *[' '.join(cell.ljust(cl) for cell, cl in zip(row, col_len))
2354 for row in table[1:]],
2355 table_formatstr,
2356 ])
2357 return textwrap.indent(rst_table, prefix=' ' * 4)
2358
2359 @classmethod
2360 @_api.deprecated(
2361 '3.10.0',
2362 message="This method is never used internally.",
2363 alternative="No replacement. Please open an issue if you use this."
2364 )
2365 def register(cls, name, style):
2366 """Register a new style."""
2367 if not issubclass(style, cls._Base):
2368 raise ValueError(f"{style} must be a subclass of {cls._Base}")
2369 cls._style_list[name] = style
2370
2371
2372def _register_style(style_list, cls=None, *, name=None):
2373 """Class decorator that stashes a class in a (style) dictionary."""
2374 if cls is None:
2375 return functools.partial(_register_style, style_list, name=name)
2376 style_list[name or cls.__name__.lower()] = cls
2377 return cls

2380@_docstring.interpd
2381class BoxStyle(_Style):
2382 """
2383 `BoxStyle` is a container class which defines several
2384 boxstyle classes, which are used for `FancyBboxPatch`.
2385
2386 A style object can be created as::
2387
2388 BoxStyle.Round(pad=0.2)
2389
2390 or::
2391
2392 BoxStyle("Round", pad=0.2)
2393
2394 or::
2395
2396 BoxStyle("Round, pad=0.2")
2397
2398 The following boxstyle classes are defined.
2399
2400 %(BoxStyle:table)s
2401
2402 An instance of a boxstyle class is a callable object, with the signature ::
2403
2404 __call__(self, x0, y0, width, height, mutation_size) -> Path
2405
2406 *x0*, *y0*, *width* and *height* specify the location and size of the box
2407 to be drawn; *mutation_size* scales the outline properties such as padding.
2408 """
2409
2410 _style_list = {}
2411
2412 @_register_style(_style_list)
2413 class Square:
2414 """A square box."""
2415
2416 def __init__(self, pad=0.3):
2417 """
2418 Parameters
2419 ----------
2420 pad : float, default: 0.3
2421 The amount of padding around the original box.
2422 """
2423 self.pad = pad
2424
2425 def __call__(self, x0, y0, width, height, mutation_size):
2426 pad = mutation_size * self.pad
2427 # width and height with padding added.
2428 width, height = width + 2 * pad, height + 2 * pad
2429 # boundary of the padded box
2430 x0, y0 = x0 - pad, y0 - pad
2431 x1, y1 = x0 + width, y0 + height
2432 return Path._create_closed(
2433 [(x0, y0), (x1, y0), (x1, y1), (x0, y1)])
2434
2435 @_register_style(_style_list)
2436 class Circle:
2437 """A circular box."""
2438
2439 def __init__(self, pad=0.3):
2440 """
2441 Parameters
2442 ----------
2443 pad : float, default: 0.3
2444 The amount of padding around the original box.
2445 """
2446 self.pad = pad
2447
2448 def __call__(self, x0, y0, width, height, mutation_size):
2449 pad = mutation_size * self.pad
2450 width, height = width + 2 * pad, height + 2 * pad
2451 # boundary of the padded box
2452 x0, y0 = x0 - pad, y0 - pad
2453 return Path.circle((x0 + width / 2, y0 + height / 2),
2454 max(width, height) / 2)

2456 @_register_style(_style_list)
2457 class Ellipse:
2458 """
2459 An elliptical box.
2460
2461 .. versionadded:: 3.7
2462 """
2463
2464 def __init__(self, pad=0.3):
2465 """
2466 Parameters
2467 ----------
2468 pad : float, default: 0.3
2469 The amount of padding around the original box.
2470 """
2471 self.pad = pad
2472
2473 def __call__(self, x0, y0, width, height, mutation_size):
2474 pad = mutation_size * self.pad
2475 width, height = width + 2 * pad, height + 2 * pad
2476 # boundary of the padded box
2477 x0, y0 = x0 - pad, y0 - pad
2478 a = width / math.sqrt(2)
2479 b = height / math.sqrt(2)
2480 trans = Affine2D().scale(a, b).translate(x0 + width / 2,
2481 y0 + height / 2)
2482 return trans.transform_path(Path.unit_circle())

2484 @_register_style(_style_list)
2485 class LArrow:
2486 """A box in the shape of a left-pointing arrow."""
2487
2488 def __init__(self, pad=0.3):
2489 """
2490 Parameters
2491 ----------
2492 pad : float, default: 0.3
2493 The amount of padding around the original box.
2494 """
2495 self.pad = pad
2496
2497 def __call__(self, x0, y0, width, height, mutation_size):
2498 # padding
2499 pad = mutation_size * self.pad
2500 # width and height with padding added.
2501 width, height = width + 2 * pad, height + 2 * pad
2502 # boundary of the padded box
2503 x0, y0 = x0 - pad, y0 - pad,
2504 x1, y1 = x0 + width, y0 + height
2505
2506 dx = (y1 - y0) / 2
2507 dxx = dx / 2
2508 x0 = x0 + pad / 1.4 # adjust by ~sqrt(2)
2509
2510 return Path._create_closed(
2511 [(x0 + dxx, y0), (x1, y0), (x1, y1), (x0 + dxx, y1),
2512 (x0 + dxx, y1 + dxx), (x0 - dx, y0 + dx),
2513 (x0 + dxx, y0 - dxx), # arrow
2514 (x0 + dxx, y0)])

2517 class RArrow(LArrow):
2518 """A box in the shape of a right-pointing arrow."""
2519
2520 def __call__(self, x0, y0, width, height, mutation_size):
2521 p = BoxStyle.LArrow.__call__(
2522 self, x0, y0, width, height, mutation_size)
2523 p.vertices[:, 0] = 2 * x0 + width - p.vertices[:, 0]
2524 return p

2526 @_register_style(_style_list)
2527 class DArrow:
2528 """A box in the shape of a two-way arrow."""
2529 # Modified from LArrow to add a right arrow to the bbox.
2530
2531 def __init__(self, pad=0.3):
2532 """
2533 Parameters
2534 ----------
2535 pad : float, default: 0.3
2536 The amount of padding around the original box.
2537 """
2538 self.pad = pad
2539
2540 def __call__(self, x0, y0, width, height, mutation_size):
2541 # padding
2542 pad = mutation_size * self.pad
2543 # width and height with padding added.
2544 # The width is padded by the arrows, so we don't need to pad it.
2545 height = height + 2 * pad
2546 # boundary of the padded box
2547 x0, y0 = x0 - pad, y0 - pad
2548 x1, y1 = x0 + width, y0 + height
2549
2550 dx = (y1 - y0) / 2
2551 dxx = dx / 2
2552 x0 = x0 + pad / 1.4 # adjust by ~sqrt(2)
2553
2554 return Path._create_closed([
2555 (x0 + dxx, y0), (x1, y0), # bot-segment
2556 (x1, y0 - dxx), (x1 + dx + dxx, y0 + dx),
2557 (x1, y1 + dxx), # right-arrow
2558 (x1, y1), (x0 + dxx, y1), # top-segment
2559 (x0 + dxx, y1 + dxx), (x0 - dx, y0 + dx),
2560 (x0 + dxx, y0 - dxx), # left-arrow
2561 (x0 + dxx, y0)])

2563 @_register_style(_style_list)
2564 class Round:
2565 """A box with round corners."""
2566
2567 def __init__(self, pad=0.3, rounding_size=None):
2568 """
2569 Parameters
2570 ----------
2571 pad : float, default: 0.3
2572 The amount of padding around the original box.
2573 rounding_size : float, default: *pad*
2574 Radius of the corners.
2575 """
2576 self.pad = pad
2577 self.rounding_size = rounding_size
2578
2579 def __call__(self, x0, y0, width, height, mutation_size):
2580
2581 # padding
2582 pad = mutation_size * self.pad
2583
2584 # size of the rounding corner
2585 if self.rounding_size:
2586 dr = mutation_size * self.rounding_size
2587 else:
2588 dr = pad
2589
2590 width, height = width + 2 * pad, height + 2 * pad
2591
2592 x0, y0 = x0 - pad, y0 - pad,
2593 x1, y1 = x0 + width, y0 + height
2594
2595 # Round corners are implemented as quadratic Bezier, e.g.,
2596 # [(x0, y0-dr), (x0, y0), (x0+dr, y0)] for lower left corner.
2597 cp = [(x0 + dr, y0),
2598 (x1 - dr, y0),
2599 (x1, y0), (x1, y0 + dr),
2600 (x1, y1 - dr),
2601 (x1, y1), (x1 - dr, y1),
2602 (x0 + dr, y1),
2603 (x0, y1), (x0, y1 - dr),
2604 (x0, y0 + dr),
2605 (x0, y0), (x0 + dr, y0),
2606 (x0 + dr, y0)]
2607
2608 com = [Path.MOVETO,
2609 Path.LINETO,
2610 Path.CURVE3, Path.CURVE3,
2611 Path.LINETO,
2612 Path.CURVE3, Path.CURVE3,
2613 Path.LINETO,
2614 Path.CURVE3, Path.CURVE3,
2615 Path.LINETO,
2616 Path.CURVE3, Path.CURVE3,
2617 Path.CLOSEPOLY]
2618
2619 return Path(cp, com)

2621 @_register_style(_style_list)
2622 class Round4:
2623 """A box with rounded edges."""
2624
2625 def __init__(self, pad=0.3, rounding_size=None):
2626 """
2627 Parameters
2628 ----------
2629 pad : float, default: 0.3
2630 The amount of padding around the original box.
2631 rounding_size : float, default: *pad*/2
2632 Rounding of edges.
2633 """
2634 self.pad = pad
2635 self.rounding_size = rounding_size
2636
2637 def __call__(self, x0, y0, width, height, mutation_size):
2638
2639 # padding
2640 pad = mutation_size * self.pad
2641
2642 # Rounding size; defaults to half of the padding.
2643 if self.rounding_size:
2644 dr = mutation_size * self.rounding_size
2645 else:
2646 dr = pad / 2.
2647
2648 width = width + 2 * pad - 2 * dr
2649 height = height + 2 * pad - 2 * dr
2650
2651 x0, y0 = x0 - pad + dr, y0 - pad + dr,
2652 x1, y1 = x0 + width, y0 + height
2653
2654 cp = [(x0, y0),
2655 (x0 + dr, y0 - dr), (x1 - dr, y0 - dr), (x1, y0),
2656 (x1 + dr, y0 + dr), (x1 + dr, y1 - dr), (x1, y1),
2657 (x1 - dr, y1 + dr), (x0 + dr, y1 + dr), (x0, y1),
2658 (x0 - dr, y1 - dr), (x0 - dr, y0 + dr), (x0, y0),
2659 (x0, y0)]
2660
2661 com = [Path.MOVETO,
2662 Path.CURVE4, Path.CURVE4, Path.CURVE4,
2663 Path.CURVE4, Path.CURVE4, Path.CURVE4,
2664 Path.CURVE4, Path.CURVE4, Path.CURVE4,
2665 Path.CURVE4, Path.CURVE4, Path.CURVE4,
2666 Path.CLOSEPOLY]
