2670 @_register_style(_style_list)
2671 class Sawtooth:
2672 """A box with a sawtooth outline."""
2673
2674 def __init__(self, pad=0.3, tooth_size=None):
2675 """
2676 Parameters
2677 ----------
2678 pad : float, default: 0.3
2679 The amount of padding around the original box.
2680 tooth_size : float, default: *pad*/2
2681 Size of the sawtooth.
2682 """
2683 self.pad = pad
2684 self.tooth_size = tooth_size
2685
2686 def _get_sawtooth_vertices(self, x0, y0, width, height, mutation_size):
2687
2688 # padding
2689 pad = mutation_size * self.pad
2690
2691 # size of sawtooth
2692 if self.tooth_size is None:
2693 tooth_size = self.pad * .5 * mutation_size
2694 else:
2695 tooth_size = self.tooth_size * mutation_size
2696
2697 hsz = tooth_size / 2
2698 width = width + 2 * pad - tooth_size
2699 height = height + 2 * pad - tooth_size
2700
2701 # the sizes of the vertical and horizontal sawtooth are
2702 # separately adjusted to fit the given box size.
2703 dsx_n = round((width - tooth_size) / (tooth_size * 2)) * 2
2704 dsy_n = round((height - tooth_size) / (tooth_size * 2)) * 2
2705
2706 x0, y0 = x0 - pad + hsz, y0 - pad + hsz
2707 x1, y1 = x0 + width, y0 + height
2708
2709 xs = [
2710 x0, *np.linspace(x0 + hsz, x1 - hsz, 2 * dsx_n + 1), # bottom
2711 *([x1, x1 + hsz, x1, x1 - hsz] * dsy_n)[:2*dsy_n+2], # right
2712 x1, *np.linspace(x1 - hsz, x0 + hsz, 2 * dsx_n + 1), # top
2713 *([x0, x0 - hsz, x0, x0 + hsz] * dsy_n)[:2*dsy_n+2], # left
2714 ]
2715 ys = [
2716 *([y0, y0 - hsz, y0, y0 + hsz] * dsx_n)[:2*dsx_n+2], # bottom
2717 y0, *np.linspace(y0 + hsz, y1 - hsz, 2 * dsy_n + 1), # right
2718 *([y1, y1 + hsz, y1, y1 - hsz] * dsx_n)[:2*dsx_n+2], # top
2719 y1, *np.linspace(y1 - hsz, y0 + hsz, 2 * dsy_n + 1), # left
2720 ]
2721
2722 return [*zip(xs, ys), (xs[0], ys[0])]
2723
2724 def __call__(self, x0, y0, width, height, mutation_size):
2725 saw_vertices = self._get_sawtooth_vertices(x0, y0, width,
2726 height, mutation_size)
2727 return Path(saw_vertices, closed=True)
2728
2729 @_register_style(_style_list)
2730 class Roundtooth(Sawtooth):
2731 """A box with a rounded sawtooth outline."""
2732
2733 def __call__(self, x0, y0, width, height, mutation_size):
2734 saw_vertices = self._get_sawtooth_vertices(x0, y0,
2735 width, height,
2736 mutation_size)
2737 # Add a trailing vertex to allow us to close the polygon correctly
2738 saw_vertices = np.concatenate([saw_vertices, [saw_vertices[0]]])
2739 codes = ([Path.MOVETO] +
2740 [Path.CURVE3, Path.CURVE3] * ((len(saw_vertices)-1)//2) +
2741 [Path.CLOSEPOLY])
2742 return Path(saw_vertices, codes)
2743
2744
2745@_docstring.interpd
2746class ConnectionStyle(_Style):
2747 """
2748 `ConnectionStyle` is a container class which defines
2749 several connectionstyle classes, which is used to create a path
2750 between two points. These are mainly used with `FancyArrowPatch`.
2751
2752 A connectionstyle object can be either created as::
2753
2754 ConnectionStyle.Arc3(rad=0.2)
2755
2756 or::
2757
2758 ConnectionStyle("Arc3", rad=0.2)
2759
2760 or::
2761
2762 ConnectionStyle("Arc3, rad=0.2")
2763
2764 The following classes are defined
2765
2766 %(ConnectionStyle:table)s
2767
2768 An instance of any connection style class is a callable object,
2769 whose call signature is::
2770
2771 __call__(self, posA, posB,
2772 patchA=None, patchB=None,
2773 shrinkA=2., shrinkB=2.)
2774
2775 and it returns a `.Path` instance. *posA* and *posB* are
2776 tuples of (x, y) coordinates of the two points to be
2777 connected. *patchA* (or *patchB*) is given, the returned path is
2778 clipped so that it start (or end) from the boundary of the
2779 patch. The path is further shrunk by *shrinkA* (or *shrinkB*)
2780 which is given in points.
2781 """
2782
2783 _style_list = {}
2784
2785 class _Base:
2786 """
2787 A base class for connectionstyle classes. The subclass needs
2788 to implement a *connect* method whose call signature is::
2789
2790 connect(posA, posB)
2791
2792 where posA and posB are tuples of x, y coordinates to be
2793 connected. The method needs to return a path connecting two
2794 points. This base class defines a __call__ method, and a few
2795 helper methods.
2796 """
2797 def _in_patch(self, patch):
2798 """
2799 Return a predicate function testing whether a point *xy* is
2800 contained in *patch*.
2801 """
2802 return lambda xy: patch.contains(
2803 SimpleNamespace(x=xy[0], y=xy[1]))[0]
2804
2805 def _clip(self, path, in_start, in_stop):
2806 """
2807 Clip *path* at its start by the region where *in_start* returns
2808 True, and at its stop by the region where *in_stop* returns True.
2809
2810 The original path is assumed to start in the *in_start* region and
2811 to stop in the *in_stop* region.
2812 """
2813 if in_start:
2814 try:
2815 _, path = split_path_inout(path, in_start)
2816 except ValueError:
2817 pass
2818 if in_stop:
2819 try:
2820 path, _ = split_path_inout(path, in_stop)
2821 except ValueError:
2822 pass
2823 return path
2824
2825 def __call__(self, posA, posB,
2826 shrinkA=2., shrinkB=2., patchA=None, patchB=None):
2827 """
2828 Call the *connect* method to create a path between *posA* and
2829 *posB*; then clip and shrink the path.
2830 """
2831 path = self.connect(posA, posB)
2832 path = self._clip(
2833 path,
2834 self._in_patch(patchA) if patchA else None,
2835 self._in_patch(patchB) if patchB else None,
2836 )
2837 path = self._clip(
2838 path,
2839 inside_circle(*path.vertices[0], shrinkA) if shrinkA else None,
2840 inside_circle(*path.vertices[-1], shrinkB) if shrinkB else None
2841 )
2842 return path
2843
2844 @_register_style(_style_list)
2845 class Arc3(_Base):
2846 """
2847 Creates a simple quadratic BÃ©zier curve between two
2848 points. The curve is created so that the middle control point
2849 (C1) is located at the same distance from the start (C0) and
2850 end points(C2) and the distance of the C1 to the line
2851 connecting C0-C2 is *rad* times the distance of C0-C2.
2852 """
2853
2854 def __init__(self, rad=0.):
2855 """
2856 Parameters
2857 ----------
2858 rad : float
2859 Curvature of the curve.
2860 """
2861 self.rad = rad
2862
2863 def connect(self, posA, posB):
2864 x1, y1 = posA
2865 x2, y2 = posB
2866 x12, y12 = (x1 + x2) / 2., (y1 + y2) / 2.
2867 dx, dy = x2 - x1, y2 - y1
2868
2869 f = self.rad
2870
2871 cx, cy = x12 + f * dy, y12 - f * dx
2872
2873 vertices = [(x1, y1),
2874 (cx, cy),
2875 (x2, y2)]
2876 codes = [Path.MOVETO,
2877 Path.CURVE3,
2878 Path.CURVE3]
2879
2880 return Path(vertices, codes)
2881
2882 @_register_style(_style_list)
2883 class Angle3(_Base):
2884 """
2885 Creates a simple quadratic BÃ©zier curve between two points. The middle
2886 control point is placed at the intersecting point of two lines which
2887 cross the start and end point, and have a slope of *angleA* and
2888 *angleB*, respectively.
2889 """
2890
2891 def __init__(self, angleA=90, angleB=0):
2892 """
2893 Parameters
2894 ----------
2895 angleA : float
2896 Starting angle of the path.
2897
2898 angleB : float
2899 Ending angle of the path.
2900 """
2901
2902 self.angleA = angleA
2903 self.angleB = angleB
2904
2905 def connect(self, posA, posB):
2906 x1, y1 = posA
2907 x2, y2 = posB
2908
2909 cosA = math.cos(math.radians(self.angleA))
2910 sinA = math.sin(math.radians(self.angleA))
2911 cosB = math.cos(math.radians(self.angleB))
2912 sinB = math.sin(math.radians(self.angleB))
2913
2914 cx, cy = get_intersection(x1, y1, cosA, sinA,
2915 x2, y2, cosB, sinB)
2916
2917 vertices = [(x1, y1), (cx, cy), (x2, y2)]
2918 codes = [Path.MOVETO, Path.CURVE3, Path.CURVE3]
2919
2920 return Path(vertices, codes)
2921
2922 @_register_style(_style_list)
2923 class Angle(_Base):
2924 """
2925 Creates a piecewise continuous quadratic BÃ©zier path between two
2926 points. The path has a one passing-through point placed at the
2927 intersecting point of two lines which cross the start and end point,
2928 and have a slope of *angleA* and *angleB*, respectively.
2929 The connecting edges are rounded with *rad*.
2930 """
2931
2932 def __init__(self, angleA=90, angleB=0, rad=0.):
2933 """
2934 Parameters
2935 ----------
2936 angleA : float
2937 Starting angle of the path.
2938
2939 angleB : float
2940 Ending angle of the path.
2941
2942 rad : float
2943 Rounding radius of the edge.
2944 """
2945
2946 self.angleA = angleA
2947 self.angleB = angleB
2948
2949 self.rad = rad
2950
2951 def connect(self, posA, posB):
2952 x1, y1 = posA
2953 x2, y2 = posB
2954
2955 cosA = math.cos(math.radians(self.angleA))
2956 sinA = math.sin(math.radians(self.angleA))
2957 cosB = math.cos(math.radians(self.angleB))
2958 sinB = math.sin(math.radians(self.angleB))
2959
2960 cx, cy = get_intersection(x1, y1, cosA, sinA,
2961 x2, y2, cosB, sinB)
2962
2963 vertices = [(x1, y1)]
2964 codes = [Path.MOVETO]
2965
2966 if self.rad == 0.:
2967 vertices.append((cx, cy))
2968 codes.append(Path.LINETO)
2969 else:
2970 dx1, dy1 = x1 - cx, y1 - cy
2971 d1 = np.hypot(dx1, dy1)
2972 f1 = self.rad / d1
2973 dx2, dy2 = x2 - cx, y2 - cy
2974 d2 = np.hypot(dx2, dy2)
2975 f2 = self.rad / d2
2976 vertices.extend([(cx + dx1 * f1, cy + dy1 * f1),
2977 (cx, cy),
2978 (cx + dx2 * f2, cy + dy2 * f2)])
2979 codes.extend([Path.LINETO, Path.CURVE3, Path.CURVE3])
2980
2981 vertices.append((x2, y2))
2982 codes.append(Path.LINETO)
2983
2984 return Path(vertices, codes)
2985
2986 @_register_style(_style_list)
2987 class Arc(_Base):
2988 """
2989 Creates a piecewise continuous quadratic BÃ©zier path between two
2990 points. The path can have two passing-through points, a
2991 point placed at the distance of *armA* and angle of *angleA* from
2992 point A, another point with respect to point B. The edges are
2993 rounded with *rad*.
2994 """
2995
2996 def __init__(self, angleA=0, angleB=0, armA=None, armB=None, rad=0.):
2997 """
2998 Parameters
2999 ----------
3000 angleA : float
3001 Starting angle of the path.
3002
3003 angleB : float
3004 Ending angle of the path.
3005
3006 armA : float or None
3007 Length of the starting arm.
3008
3009 armB : float or None
3010 Length of the ending arm.
3011
3012 rad : float
3013 Rounding radius of the edges.
3014 """
3015
3016 self.angleA = angleA
3017 self.angleB = angleB
3018 self.armA = armA
3019 self.armB = armB
3020
3021 self.rad = rad
3022
3023 def connect(self, posA, posB):
3024 x1, y1 = posA
3025 x2, y2 = posB
3026
3027 vertices = [(x1, y1)]
3028 rounded = []
3029 codes = [Path.MOVETO]
3030
3031 if self.armA:
3032 cosA = math.cos(math.radians(self.angleA))
3033 sinA = math.sin(math.radians(self.angleA))
3034 # x_armA, y_armB
3035 d = self.armA - self.rad
3036 rounded.append((x1 + d * cosA, y1 + d * sinA))
3037 d = self.armA
3038 rounded.append((x1 + d * cosA, y1 + d * sinA))
3039
3040 if self.armB:
3041 cosB = math.cos(math.radians(self.angleB))
3042 sinB = math.sin(math.radians(self.angleB))
3043 x_armB, y_armB = x2 + self.armB * cosB, y2 + self.armB * sinB
3044
3045 if rounded:
3046 xp, yp = rounded[-1]
3047 dx, dy = x_armB - xp, y_armB - yp
3048 dd = (dx * dx + dy * dy) ** .5
3049
3050 rounded.append((xp + self.rad * dx / dd,
3051 yp + self.rad * dy / dd))
3052 vertices.extend(rounded)
3053 codes.extend([Path.LINETO,
3054 Path.CURVE3,
3055 Path.CURVE3])
3056 else:
3057 xp, yp = vertices[-1]
3058 dx, dy = x_armB - xp, y_armB - yp
3059 dd = (dx * dx + dy * dy) ** .5
3060
3061 d = dd - self.rad
3062 rounded = [(xp + d * dx / dd, yp + d * dy / dd),
3063 (x_armB, y_armB)]
3064
3065 if rounded:
3066 xp, yp = rounded[-1]
3067 dx, dy = x2 - xp, y2 - yp
3068 dd = (dx * dx + dy * dy) ** .5
3069
3070 rounded.append((xp + self.rad * dx / dd,
3071 yp + self.rad * dy / dd))
3072 vertices.extend(rounded)
3073 codes.extend([Path.LINETO,
3074 Path.CURVE3,
3075 Path.CURVE3])
3076
3077 vertices.append((x2, y2))
3078 codes.append(Path.LINETO)
3079
3080 return Path(vertices, codes)
3081
3082 @_register_style(_style_list)
3083 class Bar(_Base):
3084 """
3085 A line with *angle* between A and B with *armA* and *armB*. One of the
3086 arms is extended so that they are connected in a right angle. The
3087 length of *armA* is determined by (*armA* + *fraction* x AB distance).
3088 Same for *armB*.
3089 """
3090
3091 def __init__(self, armA=0., armB=0., fraction=0.3, angle=None):
3092 """
3093 Parameters
3094 ----------
3095 armA : float
3096 Minimum length of armA.
3097
3098 armB : float
3099 Minimum length of armB.
3100
3101 fraction : float
3102 A fraction of the distance between two points that will be
3103 added to armA and armB.
3104
3105 angle : float or None
3106 Angle of the connecting line (if None, parallel to A and B).
3107 """
3108 self.armA = armA
3109 self.armB = armB
3110 self.fraction = fraction
3111 self.angle = angle
3112
3113 def connect(self, posA, posB):
3114 x1, y1 = posA
3115 x20, y20 = x2, y2 = posB
3116
3117 theta1 = math.atan2(y2 - y1, x2 - x1)
3118 dx, dy = x2 - x1, y2 - y1
3119 dd = (dx * dx + dy * dy) ** .5
3120 ddx, ddy = dx / dd, dy / dd
3121
3122 armA, armB = self.armA, self.armB
3123
3124 if self.angle is not None:
3125 theta0 = np.deg2rad(self.angle)
3126 dtheta = theta1 - theta0
3127 dl = dd * math.sin(dtheta)
3128 dL = dd * math.cos(dtheta)
3129 x2, y2 = x1 + dL * math.cos(theta0), y1 + dL * math.sin(theta0)
3130 armB = armB - dl
3131
3132 # update
3133 dx, dy = x2 - x1, y2 - y1
3134 dd2 = (dx * dx + dy * dy) ** .5
3135 ddx, ddy = dx / dd2, dy / dd2
3136
3137 arm = max(armA, armB)
3138 f = self.fraction * dd + arm
3139
3140 cx1, cy1 = x1 + f * ddy, y1 - f * ddx
3141 cx2, cy2 = x2 + f * ddy, y2 - f * ddx
3142
3143 vertices = [(x1, y1),
3144 (cx1, cy1),
3145 (cx2, cy2),
3146 (x20, y20)]
3147 codes = [Path.MOVETO,
3148 Path.LINETO,
3149 Path.LINETO,
3150 Path.LINETO]
3151
3152 return Path(vertices, codes)
3153
3154
3155def _point_along_a_line(x0, y0, x1, y1, d):
3156 """
3157 Return the point on the line connecting (*x0*, *y0*) -- (*x1*, *y1*) whose
3158 distance from (*x0*, *y0*) is *d*.
3159 """
3160 dx, dy = x0 - x1, y0 - y1
3161 ff = d / (dx * dx + dy * dy) ** .5
3162 x2, y2 = x0 - ff * dx, y0 - ff * dy
3163
3164 return x2, y2

3167@_docstring.interpd
3168class ArrowStyle(_Style):
3169 """
3170 `ArrowStyle` is a container class which defines several
3171 arrowstyle classes, which is used to create an arrow path along a
3172 given path. These are mainly used with `FancyArrowPatch`.
3173
3174 An arrowstyle object can be either created as::
3175
3176 ArrowStyle.Fancy(head_length=.4, head_width=.4, tail_width=.4)
3177
3178 or::
3179
3180 ArrowStyle("Fancy", head_length=.4, head_width=.4, tail_width=.4)
3181
3182 or::
3183
3184 ArrowStyle("Fancy, head_length=.4, head_width=.4, tail_width=.4")
3185
3186 The following classes are defined
3187
3188 %(ArrowStyle:table)s
3189
3190 For an overview of the visual appearance, see
3191 :doc:`/gallery/text_labels_and_annotations/fancyarrow_demo`.
3192
3193 An instance of any arrow style class is a callable object,
3194 whose call signature is::
3195
3196 __call__(self, path, mutation_size, linewidth, aspect_ratio=1.)
3197
3198 and it returns a tuple of a `.Path` instance and a boolean
3199 value. *path* is a `.Path` instance along which the arrow
3200 will be drawn. *mutation_size* and *aspect_ratio* have the same
3201 meaning as in `BoxStyle`. *linewidth* is a line width to be
3202 stroked. This is meant to be used to correct the location of the
3203 head so that it does not overshoot the destination point, but not all
3204 classes support it.
3205
3206 Notes
3207 -----
3208 *angleA* and *angleB* specify the orientation of the bracket, as either a
3209 clockwise or counterclockwise angle depending on the arrow type. 0 degrees
3210 means perpendicular to the line connecting the arrow's head and tail.
3211
3212 .. plot:: gallery/text_labels_and_annotations/angles_on_bracket_arrows.py
3213 """
3214
3215 _style_list = {}
3216
3217 class _Base:
3218 """
3219 Arrow Transmuter Base class
3220
3221 ArrowTransmuterBase and its derivatives are used to make a fancy
3222 arrow around a given path. The __call__ method returns a path
3223 (which will be used to create a PathPatch instance) and a boolean
3224 value indicating the path is open therefore is not fillable. This
3225 class is not an artist and actual drawing of the fancy arrow is
3226 done by the FancyArrowPatch class.
3227 """
3228
3229 # The derived classes are required to be able to be initialized
3230 # w/o arguments, i.e., all its argument (except self) must have
3231 # the default values.
3232
3233 @staticmethod
3234 def ensure_quadratic_bezier(path):
3235 """
3236 Some ArrowStyle classes only works with a simple quadratic
3237 BÃ©zier curve (created with `.ConnectionStyle.Arc3` or
3238 `.ConnectionStyle.Angle3`). This static method checks if the
3239 provided path is a simple quadratic BÃ©zier curve and returns its
3240 control points if true.
3241 """
3242 segments = list(path.iter_segments())
3243 if (len(segments) != 2 or segments[0][1] != Path.MOVETO or
3244 segments[1][1] != Path.CURVE3):
3245 raise ValueError(
3246 "'path' is not a valid quadratic Bezier curve")
3247 return [*segments[0][0], *segments[1][0]]
3248
3249 def transmute(self, path, mutation_size, linewidth):
3250 """
3251 The transmute method is the very core of the ArrowStyle class and
3252 must be overridden in the subclasses. It receives the *path*
3253 object along which the arrow will be drawn, and the
3254 *mutation_size*, with which the arrow head etc. will be scaled.
3255 The *linewidth* may be used to adjust the path so that it does not
3256 pass beyond the given points. It returns a tuple of a `.Path`
3257 instance and a boolean. The boolean value indicate whether the
3258 path can be filled or not. The return value can also be a list of
3259 paths and list of booleans of the same length.
3260 """
3261 raise NotImplementedError('Derived must override')
3262
3263 def __call__(self, path, mutation_size, linewidth,
3264 aspect_ratio=1.):
3265 """
3266 The __call__ method is a thin wrapper around the transmute method
3267 and takes care of the aspect ratio.
3268 """
3269
3270 if aspect_ratio is not None:
3271 # Squeeze the given height by the aspect_ratio
3272 vertices = path.vertices / [1, aspect_ratio]
3273 path_shrunk = Path(vertices, path.codes)
3274 # call transmute method with squeezed height.
3275 path_mutated, fillable = self.transmute(path_shrunk,
3276 mutation_size,
3277 linewidth)
3278 if np.iterable(fillable):
3279 # Restore the height
3280 path_list = [Path(p.vertices * [1, aspect_ratio], p.codes)
3281 for p in path_mutated]
3282 return path_list, fillable
3283 else:
3284 return path_mutated, fillable
3285 else:
3286 return self.transmute(path, mutation_size, linewidth)
3287
3288 class _Curve(_Base):
3289 """
3290 A simple arrow which will work with any path instance. The
3291 returned path is the concatenation of the original path, and at
3292 most two paths representing the arrow head or bracket at the start
3293 point and at the end point. The arrow heads can be either open
3294 or closed.
3295 """
3296
3297 arrow = "-"
3298 fillbegin = fillend = False # Whether arrows are filled.
3299
3300 def __init__(self, head_length=.4, head_width=.2, widthA=1., widthB=1.,
3301 lengthA=0.2, lengthB=0.2, angleA=0, angleB=0, scaleA=None,
3302 scaleB=None):
3303 """
3304 Parameters
3305 ----------
3306 head_length : float, default: 0.4
3307 Length of the arrow head, relative to *mutation_size*.
3308 head_width : float, default: 0.2
3309 Width of the arrow head, relative to *mutation_size*.
3310 widthA, widthB : float, default: 1.0
3311 Width of the bracket.
3312 lengthA, lengthB : float, default: 0.2
3313 Length of the bracket.
3314 angleA, angleB : float, default: 0
3315 Orientation of the bracket, as a counterclockwise angle.
3316 0 degrees means perpendicular to the line.
3317 scaleA, scaleB : float, default: *mutation_size*
3318 The scale of the brackets.
3319 """
3320
3321 self.head_length, self.head_width = head_length, head_width
3322 self.widthA, self.widthB = widthA, widthB
3323 self.lengthA, self.lengthB = lengthA, lengthB
3324 self.angleA, self.angleB = angleA, angleB
3325 self.scaleA, self.scaleB = scaleA, scaleB
3326
3327 self._beginarrow_head = False
3328 self._beginarrow_bracket = False
3329 self._endarrow_head = False
3330 self._endarrow_bracket = False
3331
3332 if "-" not in self.arrow:
3333 raise ValueError("arrow must have the '-' between "
3334 "the two heads")
3335
3336 beginarrow, endarrow = self.arrow.split("-", 1)
3337
3338 if beginarrow == "<":
3339 self._beginarrow_head = True
3340 self._beginarrow_bracket = False
3341 elif beginarrow == "<|":
3342 self._beginarrow_head = True
3343 self._beginarrow_bracket = False
3344 self.fillbegin = True
3345 elif beginarrow in ("]", "|"):
3346 self._beginarrow_head = False
3347 self._beginarrow_bracket = True
3348
3349 if endarrow == ">":
3350 self._endarrow_head = True
3351 self._endarrow_bracket = False
3352 elif endarrow == "|>":
3353 self._endarrow_head = True
3354 self._endarrow_bracket = False
3355 self.fillend = True
3356 elif endarrow in ("[", "|"):
3357 self._endarrow_head = False
3358 self._endarrow_bracket = True
3359
3360 super().__init__()
3361
3362 def _get_arrow_wedge(self, x0, y0, x1, y1,
3363 head_dist, cos_t, sin_t, linewidth):
3364 """
3365 Return the paths for arrow heads. Since arrow lines are
3366 drawn with capstyle=projected, The arrow goes beyond the
3367 desired point. This method also returns the amount of the path
3368 to be shrunken so that it does not overshoot.
3369 """
3370
3371 # arrow from x0, y0 to x1, y1
3372 dx, dy = x0 - x1, y0 - y1
3373
3374 cp_distance = np.hypot(dx, dy)
3375
3376 # pad_projected : amount of pad to account the
3377 # overshooting of the projection of the wedge
3378 pad_projected = (.5 * linewidth / sin_t)
3379
3380 # Account for division by zero
3381 if cp_distance == 0:
3382 cp_distance = 1
3383
3384 # apply pad for projected edge
3385 ddx = pad_projected * dx / cp_distance
3386 ddy = pad_projected * dy / cp_distance
3387
3388 # offset for arrow wedge
3389 dx = dx / cp_distance * head_dist
3390 dy = dy / cp_distance * head_dist
3391
3392 dx1, dy1 = cos_t * dx + sin_t * dy, -sin_t * dx + cos_t * dy
3393 dx2, dy2 = cos_t * dx - sin_t * dy, sin_t * dx + cos_t * dy
3394
3395 vertices_arrow = [(x1 + ddx + dx1, y1 + ddy + dy1),
3396 (x1 + ddx, y1 + ddy),
3397 (x1 + ddx + dx2, y1 + ddy + dy2)]
3398 codes_arrow = [Path.MOVETO,
3399 Path.LINETO,
3400 Path.LINETO]
3401
3402 return vertices_arrow, codes_arrow, ddx, ddy
3403
3404 def _get_bracket(self, x0, y0,
3405 x1, y1, width, length, angle):
3406
3407 cos_t, sin_t = get_cos_sin(x1, y1, x0, y0)
3408
3409 # arrow from x0, y0 to x1, y1
3410 from matplotlib.bezier import get_normal_points
3411 x1, y1, x2, y2 = get_normal_points(x0, y0, cos_t, sin_t, width)
3412
3413 dx, dy = length * cos_t, length * sin_t
3414
3415 vertices_arrow = [(x1 + dx, y1 + dy),
3416 (x1, y1),
3417 (x2, y2),
3418 (x2 + dx, y2 + dy)]
3419 codes_arrow = [Path.MOVETO,
3420 Path.LINETO,
3421 Path.LINETO,
3422 Path.LINETO]
3423
3424 if angle:
3425 trans = transforms.Affine2D().rotate_deg_around(x0, y0, angle)
3426 vertices_arrow = trans.transform(vertices_arrow)
3427
3428 return vertices_arrow, codes_arrow
3429
3430 def transmute(self, path, mutation_size, linewidth):
3431 # docstring inherited
3432 if self._beginarrow_head or self._endarrow_head:
3433 head_length = self.head_length * mutation_size
3434 head_width = self.head_width * mutation_size
3435 head_dist = np.hypot(head_length, head_width)
3436 cos_t, sin_t = head_length / head_dist, head_width / head_dist
3437
3438 scaleA = mutation_size if self.scaleA is None else self.scaleA
3439 scaleB = mutation_size if self.scaleB is None else self.scaleB
3440
3441 # begin arrow
3442 x0, y0 = path.vertices[0]
3443 x1, y1 = path.vertices[1]
3444
3445 # If there is no room for an arrow and a line, then skip the arrow
3446 has_begin_arrow = self._beginarrow_head and (x0, y0) != (x1, y1)
3447 verticesA, codesA, ddxA, ddyA = (
3448 self._get_arrow_wedge(x1, y1, x0, y0,
3449 head_dist, cos_t, sin_t, linewidth)
3450 if has_begin_arrow
3451 else ([], [], 0, 0)
3452 )
3453
3454 # end arrow
3455 x2, y2 = path.vertices[-2]
3456 x3, y3 = path.vertices[-1]
3457
3458 # If there is no room for an arrow and a line, then skip the arrow
3459 has_end_arrow = self._endarrow_head and (x2, y2) != (x3, y3)
3460 verticesB, codesB, ddxB, ddyB = (
3461 self._get_arrow_wedge(x2, y2, x3, y3,
3462 head_dist, cos_t, sin_t, linewidth)
3463 if has_end_arrow
3464 else ([], [], 0, 0)
3465 )
3466
3467 # This simple code will not work if ddx, ddy is greater than the
3468 # separation between vertices.
3469 paths = [Path(np.concatenate([[(x0 + ddxA, y0 + ddyA)],
3470 path.vertices[1:-1],
3471 [(x3 + ddxB, y3 + ddyB)]]),
3472 path.codes)]
3473 fills = [False]
3474
3475 if has_begin_arrow:
3476 if self.fillbegin:
3477 paths.append(
3478 Path([*verticesA, (0, 0)], [*codesA, Path.CLOSEPOLY]))
3479 fills.append(True)
3480 else:
3481 paths.append(Path(verticesA, codesA))
3482 fills.append(False)
3483 elif self._beginarrow_bracket:
3484 x0, y0 = path.vertices[0]
3485 x1, y1 = path.vertices[1]
3486 verticesA, codesA = self._get_bracket(x0, y0, x1, y1,
3487 self.widthA * scaleA,
3488 self.lengthA * scaleA,
3489 self.angleA)
3490
3491 paths.append(Path(verticesA, codesA))
3492 fills.append(False)
3493
3494 if has_end_arrow:
3495 if self.fillend:
3496 fills.append(True)
3497 paths.append(
3498 Path([*verticesB, (0, 0)], [*codesB, Path.CLOSEPOLY]))
3499 else:
3500 fills.append(False)
3501 paths.append(Path(verticesB, codesB))
3502 elif self._endarrow_bracket:
3503 x0, y0 = path.vertices[-1]
3504 x1, y1 = path.vertices[-2]
3505 verticesB, codesB = self._get_bracket(x0, y0, x1, y1,
3506 self.widthB * scaleB,
3507 self.lengthB * scaleB,
3508 self.angleB)
3509
3510 paths.append(Path(verticesB, codesB))
3511 fills.append(False)
3512
3513 return paths, fills

3515 @_register_style(_style_list, name="-")

3521 # if someone modifies beginarrow/etc. on an ArrowStyle instance.
3522 super().__init__(head_length=.2, head_width=.1)

3678 """A simple arrow. Only works with a quadratic BÃ©zier curve."""
3679
3680 def __init__(self, head_length=.5, head_width=.5, tail_width=.2):
3681 """
3682 Parameters
3683 ----------
3684 head_length : float, default: 0.5
3685 Length of the arrow head.
3686
3687 head_width : float, default: 0.5
3688 Width of the arrow head.
3689
3690 tail_width : float, default: 0.2
3691 Width of the arrow tail.
3692 """
3693 self.head_length, self.head_width, self.tail_width = \
3694 head_length, head_width, tail_width
3695 super().__init__()
3696
3697 def transmute(self, path, mutation_size, linewidth):
3698 # docstring inherited
3699 x0, y0, x1, y1, x2, y2 = self.ensure_quadratic_bezier(path)
3700
3701 # divide the path into a head and a tail
3702 head_length = self.head_length * mutation_size
3703 in_f = inside_circle(x2, y2, head_length)
3704 arrow_path = [(x0, y0), (x1, y1), (x2, y2)]
3705
3706 try:
3707 arrow_out, arrow_in = \
3708 split_bezier_intersecting_with_closedpath(arrow_path, in_f)
3709 except NonIntersectingPathException:
3710 # if this happens, make a straight line of the head_length
3711 # long.
3712 x0, y0 = _point_along_a_line(x2, y2, x1, y1, head_length)
3713 x1n, y1n = 0.5 * (x0 + x2), 0.5 * (y0 + y2)
3714 arrow_in = [(x0, y0), (x1n, y1n), (x2, y2)]
3715 arrow_out = None
3716
3717 # head
3718 head_width = self.head_width * mutation_size
3719 head_left, head_right = make_wedged_bezier2(arrow_in,
3720 head_width / 2., wm=.5)
3721
3722 # tail
3723 if arrow_out is not None:
3724 tail_width = self.tail_width * mutation_size
3725 tail_left, tail_right = get_parallels(arrow_out,
3726 tail_width / 2.)
3727
3728 patch_path = [(Path.MOVETO, tail_right[0]),
3729 (Path.CURVE3, tail_right[1]),
3730 (Path.CURVE3, tail_right[2]),
3731 (Path.LINETO, head_right[0]),
3732 (Path.CURVE3, head_right[1]),
3733 (Path.CURVE3, head_right[2]),
3734 (Path.CURVE3, head_left[1]),
3735 (Path.CURVE3, head_left[0]),
3736 (Path.LINETO, tail_left[2]),
3737 (Path.CURVE3, tail_left[1]),
3738 (Path.CURVE3, tail_left[0]),
3739 (Path.LINETO, tail_right[0]),
3740 (Path.CLOSEPOLY, tail_right[0]),
3741 ]
3742 else:
3743 patch_path = [(Path.MOVETO, head_right[0]),
3744 (Path.CURVE3, head_right[1]),
3745 (Path.CURVE3, head_right[2]),
3746 (Path.CURVE3, head_left[1]),
3747 (Path.CURVE3, head_left[0]),
3748 (Path.CLOSEPOLY, head_left[0]),
3749 ]
3750
3751 path = Path([p for c, p in patch_path], [c for c, p in patch_path])
3752
3753 return path, True

3777 # docstring inherited
3778 x0, y0, x1, y1, x2, y2 = self.ensure_quadratic_bezier(path)
3779
3780 # divide the path into a head and a tail
3781 head_length = self.head_length * mutation_size
3782 arrow_path = [(x0, y0), (x1, y1), (x2, y2)]
3783
3784 # path for head
3785 in_f = inside_circle(x2, y2, head_length)
3786 try:
3787 path_out, path_in = split_bezier_intersecting_with_closedpath(
3788 arrow_path, in_f)
3789 except NonIntersectingPathException:
3790 # if this happens, make a straight line of the head_length
3791 # long.
3792 x0, y0 = _point_along_a_line(x2, y2, x1, y1, head_length)
3793 x1n, y1n = 0.5 * (x0 + x2), 0.5 * (y0 + y2)

3795 path_head = arrow_path
3796 else:
3797 path_head = path_in
3798
3799 # path for head
3800 in_f = inside_circle(x2, y2, head_length * .8)
3801 path_out, path_in = split_bezier_intersecting_with_closedpath(
3802 arrow_path, in_f)
3803 path_tail = path_out
3804
3805 # head

3808 head_width / 2.,

3810
3811 # tail

3813 tail_left, tail_right = make_wedged_bezier2(path_tail,
3814 tail_width * .5,
3815 w1=1., wm=0.6, w2=0.3)
3816
3817 # path for head
3818 in_f = inside_circle(x0, y0, tail_width * .3)
3819 path_in, path_out = split_bezier_intersecting_with_closedpath(
3820 arrow_path, in_f)
3821 tail_start = path_in[-1]
3822
3823 head_right, head_left = head_r, head_l
3824 patch_path = [(Path.MOVETO, tail_start),
3825 (Path.LINETO, tail_right[0]),
3826 (Path.CURVE3, tail_right[1]),
3827 (Path.CURVE3, tail_right[2]),
3828 (Path.LINETO, head_right[0]),
3829 (Path.CURVE3, head_right[1]),
3830 (Path.CURVE3, head_right[2]),
3831 (Path.CURVE3, head_left[1]),
3832 (Path.CURVE3, head_left[0]),
3833 (Path.LINETO, tail_left[2]),
3834 (Path.CURVE3, tail_left[1]),
3835 (Path.CURVE3, tail_left[0]),
3836 (Path.LINETO, tail_start),
3837 (Path.CLOSEPOLY, tail_start),
3838 ]
3839 path = Path([p for c, p in patch_path], [c for c, p in patch_path])

3846 Wedge(?) shape. Only works with a quadratic BÃ©zier curve. The
3847 start point has a width of the *tail_width* and the end point has a
3848 width of 0. At the middle, the width is *shrink_factor*x*tail_width*.
3849 """

3852 """

3862 self.shrink_factor = shrink_factor

3865 def transmute(self, path, mutation_size, linewidth):
3866 # docstring inherited

3868
3869 arrow_path = [(x0, y0), (x1, y1), (x2, y2)]
3870 b_plus, b_minus = make_wedged_bezier2(
3871 arrow_path,
3872 self.tail_width * mutation_size / 2.,
3873 wm=self.shrink_factor)
3874

3876 (Path.CURVE3, b_plus[1]),

3878 (Path.LINETO, b_minus[2]),
3879 (Path.CURVE3, b_minus[1]),
3880 (Path.CURVE3, b_minus[0]),
3881 (Path.CLOSEPOLY, b_minus[0]),
3882 ]

3888class FancyBboxPatch(Patch):
3889 """
3890 A fancy box around a rectangle with lower left at *xy* = (*x*, *y*)
3891 with specified width and height.
3892
3893 `.FancyBboxPatch` is similar to `.Rectangle`, but it draws a fancy box
3894 around the rectangle. The transformation of the rectangle box to the
3895 fancy box is delegated to the style classes defined in `.BoxStyle`.
3896 """
3897
3898 _edge_default = True
3899
3900 def __str__(self):
3901 s = self.__class__.__name__ + "((%g, %g), width=%g, height=%g)"
3902 return s % (self._x, self._y, self._width, self._height)
3903
3904 @_docstring.interpd
3905 def __init__(self, xy, width, height, boxstyle="round", *,
3906 mutation_scale=1, mutation_aspect=1, **kwargs):
3907 """
3908 Parameters
3909 ----------
3910 xy : (float, float)
3911 The lower left corner of the box.
3912
3913 width : float
3914 The width of the box.
3915
3916 height : float
3917 The height of the box.
3918
3919 boxstyle : str or `~matplotlib.patches.BoxStyle`
3920 The style of the fancy box. This can either be a `.BoxStyle`
3921 instance or a string of the style name and optionally comma
3922 separated attributes (e.g. "Round, pad=0.2"). This string is
3923 passed to `.BoxStyle` to construct a `.BoxStyle` object. See
3924 there for a full documentation.
3925
3926 The following box styles are available:
3927
3928 %(BoxStyle:table)s
3929
3930 mutation_scale : float, default: 1
3931 Scaling factor applied to the attributes of the box style
3932 (e.g. pad or rounding_size).
3933
3934 mutation_aspect : float, default: 1
3935 The height of the rectangle will be squeezed by this value before
3936 the mutation and the mutated box will be stretched by the inverse
3937 of it. For example, this allows different horizontal and vertical
3938 padding.
3939
3940 Other Parameters
3941 ----------------
3942 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Patch` properties
3943
3944 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
3945 """
3946
3947 super().__init__(**kwargs)
3948 self._x, self._y = xy
3949 self._width = width
3950 self._height = height
3951 self.set_boxstyle(boxstyle)
3952 self._mutation_scale = mutation_scale
3953 self._mutation_aspect = mutation_aspect
3954 self.stale = True

3956 @_docstring.interpd

3958 """
3959 Set the box style, possibly with further attributes.
3960
3961 Attributes from the previous box style are not reused.
3962
3963 Without argument (or with ``boxstyle=None``), the available box styles

3990 return BoxStyle.pprint_styles()

4031 def get_path(self):
4032 """Return the mutated path of the rectangle."""
4033 boxstyle = self.get_boxstyle()
4034 m_aspect = self.get_mutation_aspect()
4035 # Call boxstyle with y, height squeezed by aspect_ratio.
4036 path = boxstyle(self._x, self._y / m_aspect,
4037 self._width, self._height / m_aspect,
4038 self.get_mutation_scale())
4039 return Path(path.vertices * [1, m_aspect], path.codes) # Unsqueeze y.

4135class FancyArrowPatch(Patch):
4136 """
4137 A fancy arrow patch.
4138
4139 It draws an arrow using the `ArrowStyle`. It is primarily used by the
4140 `~.axes.Axes.annotate` method. For most purposes, use the annotate method for
4141 drawing arrows.
4142
4143 The head and tail positions are fixed at the specified start and end points
4144 of the arrow, but the size and shape (in display coordinates) of the arrow
4145 does not change when the axis is moved or zoomed.
4146 """
4147 _edge_default = True
4148
4149 def __str__(self):
4150 if self._posA_posB is not None:
4151 (x1, y1), (x2, y2) = self._posA_posB
4152 return f"{type(self).__name__}(({x1:g}, {y1:g})->({x2:g}, {y2:g}))"
4153 else:
4154 return f"{type(self).__name__}({self._path_original})"
4155
4156 @_docstring.interpd
4157 def __init__(self, posA=None, posB=None, *,
4158 path=None, arrowstyle="simple", connectionstyle="arc3",
4159 patchA=None, patchB=None, shrinkA=2, shrinkB=2,
4160 mutation_scale=1, mutation_aspect=1, **kwargs):
4161 """
4162 **Defining the arrow position and path**
4163
4164 There are two ways to define the arrow position and path:
4165
4166 - **Start, end and connection**:
4167 The typical approach is to define the start and end points of the
4168 arrow using *posA* and *posB*. The curve between these two can
4169 further be configured using *connectionstyle*.
4170
4171 If given, the arrow curve is clipped by *patchA* and *patchB*,
4172 allowing it to start/end at the border of these patches.
4173 Additionally, the arrow curve can be shortened by *shrinkA* and *shrinkB*
4174 to create a margin between start/end (after possible clipping) and the
4175 drawn arrow.
4176
4177 - **path**: Alternatively if *path* is provided, an arrow is drawn along
4178 this Path. In this case, *connectionstyle*, *patchA*, *patchB*,
4179 *shrinkA*, and *shrinkB* are ignored.
4180
4181 **Styling**
4182
4183 The *arrowstyle* defines the styling of the arrow head, tail and shaft.
4184 The resulting arrows can be styled further by setting the `.Patch`
4185 properties such as *linewidth*, *color*, *facecolor*, *edgecolor*
4186 etc. via keyword arguments.
4187
4188 Parameters
4189 ----------
4190 posA, posB : (float, float), optional
4191 (x, y) coordinates of start and end point of the arrow.
4192 The actually drawn start and end positions may be modified
4193 through *patchA*, *patchB*, *shrinkA*, and *shrinkB*.
4194
4195 *posA*, *posB* are exclusive of *path*.
4196
4197 path : `~matplotlib.path.Path`, optional
4198 If provided, an arrow is drawn along this path and *patchA*,
4199 *patchB*, *shrinkA*, and *shrinkB* are ignored.
4200
4201 *path* is exclusive of *posA*, *posB*.
4202
4203 arrowstyle : str or `.ArrowStyle`, default: 'simple'
4204 The styling of arrow head, tail and shaft. This can be
4205
4206 - `.ArrowStyle` or one of its subclasses
4207 - The shorthand string name (e.g. "->") as given in the table below,
4208 optionally containing a comma-separated list of style parameters,
4209 e.g. "->, head_length=10, head_width=5".
4210
4211 The style parameters are scaled by *mutation_scale*.
4212
4213 The following arrow styles are available. See also
4214 :doc:`/gallery/text_labels_and_annotations/fancyarrow_demo`.
4215
4216 %(ArrowStyle:table)s
4217
4218 Only the styles ``<|-``, ``-|>``, ``<|-|>`` ``simple``, ``fancy``
4219 and ``wedge`` contain closed paths and can be filled.
4220
4221 connectionstyle : str or `.ConnectionStyle` or None, optional, \
4222default: 'arc3'
4223 `.ConnectionStyle` with which *posA* and *posB* are connected.
4224 This can be
4225
4226 - `.ConnectionStyle` or one of its subclasses
4227 - The shorthand string name as given in the table below, e.g. "arc3".
4228
4229 %(ConnectionStyle:table)s
4230
4231 Ignored if *path* is provided.
4232
4233 patchA, patchB : `~matplotlib.patches.Patch`, default: None
4234 Optional Patches at *posA* and *posB*, respectively. If given,
4235 the arrow path is clipped by these patches such that head and tail
4236 are at the border of the patches.
4237
4238 Ignored if *path* is provided.
4239
4240 shrinkA, shrinkB : float, default: 2
4241 Shorten the arrow path at *posA* and *posB* by this amount in points.
4242 This allows to add a margin between the intended start/end points and
4243 the arrow.
4244
4245 Ignored if *path* is provided.
4246
4247 mutation_scale : float, default: 1
4248 Value with which attributes of *arrowstyle* (e.g., *head_length*)
4249 will be scaled.
4250
4251 mutation_aspect : None or float, default: None
4252 The height of the rectangle will be squeezed by this value before
4253 the mutation and the mutated box will be stretched by the inverse
4254 of it.
4255
4256 Other Parameters
4257 ----------------
4258 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Patch` properties, optional
4259 Here is a list of available `.Patch` properties:
4260
4261 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
4262
4263 In contrast to other patches, the default ``capstyle`` and
4264 ``joinstyle`` for `FancyArrowPatch` are set to ``"round"``.
4265 """
4266 # Traditionally, the cap- and joinstyle for FancyArrowPatch are round
4267 kwargs.setdefault("joinstyle", JoinStyle.round)
4268 kwargs.setdefault("capstyle", CapStyle.round)
4269
4270 super().__init__(**kwargs)
4271
4272 if posA is not None and posB is not None and path is None:
4273 self._posA_posB = [posA, posB]
4274
4275 if connectionstyle is None:
4276 connectionstyle = "arc3"
4277 self.set_connectionstyle(connectionstyle)
4278
4279 elif posA is None and posB is None and path is not None:
4280 self._posA_posB = None
4281 else:
4282 raise ValueError("Either posA and posB, or path need to provided")
4283
4284 self.patchA = patchA
4285 self.patchB = patchB
4286 self.shrinkA = shrinkA
4287 self.shrinkB = shrinkB
4288
4289 self._path_original = path
4290
4291 self.set_arrowstyle(arrowstyle)
4292
4293 self._mutation_scale = mutation_scale
4294 self._mutation_aspect = mutation_aspect
4295
4296 self._dpi_cor = 1.0
4297

4301
4302 Parameters

4305 (x, y) coordinates of arrow tail and arrow head respectively. If
4306 `None` use current value.
4307 """
4308 if posA is not None:
4309 self._posA_posB[0] = posA
4310 if posB is not None:
4311 self._posA_posB[1] = posB
4312 self.stale = True

4461 def get_path(self):
4462 """Return the path of the arrow in the data coordinates."""
4463 # The path is generated in display coordinates, then converted back to
4464 # data coordinates.
4465 _path, fillable = self._get_path_in_displaycoord()
4466 if np.iterable(fillable):
4467 _path = Path.make_compound_path(*_path)
4468 return self.get_transform().inverted().transform_path(_path)
4469
4470 def _get_path_in_displaycoord(self):
4471 """Return the mutated path of the arrow in display coordinates."""
4472 dpi_cor = self._dpi_cor
4473
4474 if self._posA_posB is not None:
4475 posA = self._convert_xy_units(self._posA_posB[0])
4476 posB = self._convert_xy_units(self._posA_posB[1])
4477 (posA, posB) = self.get_transform().transform((posA, posB))
4478 _path = self.get_connectionstyle()(posA, posB,
4479 patchA=self.patchA,
4480 patchB=self.patchB,
4481 shrinkA=self.shrinkA * dpi_cor,
4482 shrinkB=self.shrinkB * dpi_cor
4483 )
4484 else:
4485 _path = self.get_transform().transform_path(self._path_original)
4486
4487 _path, fillable = self.get_arrowstyle()(
4488 _path,
4489 self.get_mutation_scale() * dpi_cor,
4490 self.get_linewidth() * dpi_cor,
4491 self.get_mutation_aspect())
4492
4493 return _path, fillable
4494
4495 def draw(self, renderer):
4496 if not self.get_visible():
4497 return
4498
4499 # FIXME: dpi_cor is for the dpi-dependency of the linewidth. There
4500 # could be room for improvement. Maybe _get_path_in_displaycoord could
4501 # take a renderer argument, but get_path should be adapted too.
4502 self._dpi_cor = renderer.points_to_pixels(1.)
4503 path, fillable = self._get_path_in_displaycoord()
4504
4505 if not np.iterable(fillable):
4506 path = [path]
4507 fillable = [fillable]
4508
4509 affine = transforms.IdentityTransform()
4510
4511 self._draw_paths_with_artist_properties(
4512 renderer,
4513 [(p, affine, self._facecolor if f and self._facecolor[3] else None)
4514 for p, f in zip(path, fillable)])

4517class ConnectionPatch(FancyArrowPatch):
4518 """A patch that connects two points (possibly in different Axes)."""
4519
4520 def __str__(self):
4521 return "ConnectionPatch((%g, %g), (%g, %g))" % \
4522 (self.xy1[0], self.xy1[1], self.xy2[0], self.xy2[1])
4523
4524 @_docstring.interpd
4525 def __init__(self, xyA, xyB, coordsA, coordsB=None, *,
4526 axesA=None, axesB=None,
4527 arrowstyle="-",
4528 connectionstyle="arc3",
4529 patchA=None,
4530 patchB=None,
4531 shrinkA=0.,
4532 shrinkB=0.,
4533 mutation_scale=10.,
4534 mutation_aspect=None,
4535 clip_on=False,
4536 **kwargs):
4537 """
4538 Connect point *xyA* in *coordsA* with point *xyB* in *coordsB*.
4539
4540 Valid keys are
4541
4542 =============== ======================================================
4543 Key Description
4544 =============== ======================================================
4545 arrowstyle the arrow style
4546 connectionstyle the connection style
4547 relpos default is (0.5, 0.5)
4548 patchA default is bounding box of the text
4549 patchB default is None
4550 shrinkA default is 2 points
4551 shrinkB default is 2 points
4552 mutation_scale default is text size (in points)
4553 mutation_aspect default is 1.
4554 ? any key for `matplotlib.patches.PathPatch`
4555 =============== ======================================================
4556
4557 *coordsA* and *coordsB* are strings that indicate the
4558 coordinates of *xyA* and *xyB*.
4559
4560 ==================== ==================================================
4561 Property Description
4562 ==================== ==================================================
4563 'figure points' points from the lower left corner of the figure
4564 'figure pixels' pixels from the lower left corner of the figure
4565 'figure fraction' 0, 0 is lower left of figure and 1, 1 is upper
4566 right
4567 'subfigure points' points from the lower left corner of the subfigure
4568 'subfigure pixels' pixels from the lower left corner of the subfigure
4569 'subfigure fraction' fraction of the subfigure, 0, 0 is lower left.
4570 'axes points' points from lower left corner of the Axes
4571 'axes pixels' pixels from lower left corner of the Axes
4572 'axes fraction' 0, 0 is lower left of Axes and 1, 1 is upper right
4573 'data' use the coordinate system of the object being
4574 annotated (default)
4575 'offset points' offset (in points) from the *xy* value
4576 'polar' you can specify *theta*, *r* for the annotation,
4577 even in cartesian plots. Note that if you are
4578 using a polar Axes, you do not need to specify
4579 polar for the coordinate system since that is the
4580 native "data" coordinate system.
4581 ==================== ==================================================
4582
4583 Alternatively they can be set to any valid
4584 `~matplotlib.transforms.Transform`.
4585
4586 Note that 'subfigure pixels' and 'figure pixels' are the same
4587 for the parent figure, so users who want code that is usable in
4588 a subfigure can use 'subfigure pixels'.
4589
4590 .. note::
4591
4592 Using `ConnectionPatch` across two `~.axes.Axes` instances
4593 is not directly compatible with :ref:`constrained layout
4594 <constrainedlayout_guide>`. Add the artist
4595 directly to the `.Figure` instead of adding it to a specific Axes,
4596 or exclude it from the layout using ``con.set_in_layout(False)``.
4597
4598 .. code-block:: default
4599
4600 fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 2, constrained_layout=True)
4601 con = ConnectionPatch(..., axesA=ax[0], axesB=ax[1])
4602 fig.add_artist(con)
4603
4604 """
4605 if coordsB is None:
4606 coordsB = coordsA
4607 # we'll draw ourself after the artist we annotate by default
4608 self.xy1 = xyA
4609 self.xy2 = xyB
4610 self.coords1 = coordsA
4611 self.coords2 = coordsB
4612
4613 self.axesA = axesA
4614 self.axesB = axesB
4615
4616 super().__init__(posA=(0, 0), posB=(1, 1),
4617 arrowstyle=arrowstyle,
4618 connectionstyle=connectionstyle,
4619 patchA=patchA, patchB=patchB,
4620 shrinkA=shrinkA, shrinkB=shrinkB,
4621 mutation_scale=mutation_scale,
4622 mutation_aspect=mutation_aspect,
4623 clip_on=clip_on,
4624 **kwargs)
4625 # if True, draw annotation only if self.xy is inside the Axes
4626 self._annotation_clip = None
4627
4628 def _get_xy(self, xy, s, axes=None):
4629 """Calculate the pixel position of given point."""
4630 s0 = s # For the error message, if needed.
4631 if axes is None:
4632 axes = self.axes
4633
4634 # preserve mixed type input (such as str, int)
4635 x = np.array(xy[0])
4636 y = np.array(xy[1])
4637
4638 fig = self.get_figure(root=False)
4639 if s in ["figure points", "axes points"]:
4640 x = x * fig.dpi / 72
4641 y = y * fig.dpi / 72
4642 s = s.replace("points", "pixels")
4643 elif s == "figure fraction":
4644 s = fig.transFigure
4645 elif s == "subfigure fraction":
4646 s = fig.transSubfigure
4647 elif s == "axes fraction":
4648 s = axes.transAxes
4649
4650 if s == 'data':
4651 trans = axes.transData
4652 x = cbook._to_unmasked_float_array(axes.xaxis.convert_units(x))
4653 y = cbook._to_unmasked_float_array(axes.yaxis.convert_units(y))
4654 return trans.transform((x, y))
4655 elif s == 'offset points':
4656 if self.xycoords == 'offset points': # prevent recursion
4657 return self._get_xy(self.xy, 'data')
4658 return (
4659 self._get_xy(self.xy, self.xycoords) # converted data point
4660 + xy * self.get_figure(root=True).dpi / 72) # converted offset
4661 elif s == 'polar':
4662 theta, r = x, y
4663 x = r * np.cos(theta)
4664 y = r * np.sin(theta)
4665 trans = axes.transData
4666 return trans.transform((x, y))
4667 elif s == 'figure pixels':
4668 # pixels from the lower left corner of the figure
4669 bb = self.get_figure(root=False).figbbox
4670 x = bb.x0 + x if x >= 0 else bb.x1 + x
4671 y = bb.y0 + y if y >= 0 else bb.y1 + y
4672 return x, y
4673 elif s == 'subfigure pixels':
4674 # pixels from the lower left corner of the figure
4675 bb = self.get_figure(root=False).bbox
4676 x = bb.x0 + x if x >= 0 else bb.x1 + x
4677 y = bb.y0 + y if y >= 0 else bb.y1 + y
4678 return x, y
4679 elif s == 'axes pixels':
4680 # pixels from the lower left corner of the Axes
4681 bb = axes.bbox
4682 x = bb.x0 + x if x >= 0 else bb.x1 + x
4683 y = bb.y0 + y if y >= 0 else bb.y1 + y
4684 return x, y
4685 elif isinstance(s, transforms.Transform):
4686 return s.transform(xy)
4687 else:
4688 raise ValueError(f"{s0} is not a valid coordinate transformation")
4689
4690 def set_annotation_clip(self, b):
4691 """
4692 Set the annotation's clipping behavior.
4693
4694 Parameters
4695 ----------
4696 b : bool or None
4697 - True: The annotation will be clipped when ``self.xy`` is
4698 outside the Axes.
4699 - False: The annotation will always be drawn.
4700 - None: The annotation will be clipped when ``self.xy`` is
4701 outside the Axes and ``self.xycoords == "data"``.
4702 """
4703 self._annotation_clip = b
4704 self.stale = True
4705
4706 def get_annotation_clip(self):
4707 """
4708 Return the clipping behavior.
4709
4710 See `.set_annotation_clip` for the meaning of the return value.
4711 """
4712 return self._annotation_clip
4713
4714 def _get_path_in_displaycoord(self):
4715 """Return the mutated path of the arrow in display coordinates."""
4716 dpi_cor = self._dpi_cor
4717 posA = self._get_xy(self.xy1, self.coords1, self.axesA)
4718 posB = self._get_xy(self.xy2, self.coords2, self.axesB)
4719 path = self.get_connectionstyle()(
4720 posA, posB,
4721 patchA=self.patchA, patchB=self.patchB,
4722 shrinkA=self.shrinkA * dpi_cor, shrinkB=self.shrinkB * dpi_cor,
4723 )
4724 path, fillable = self.get_arrowstyle()(
4725 path,
4726 self.get_mutation_scale() * dpi_cor,
4727 self.get_linewidth() * dpi_cor,
4728 self.get_mutation_aspect()
4729 )
4730 return path, fillable
4731
4732 def _check_xy(self, renderer):
4733 """Check whether the annotation needs to be drawn."""
4734
4735 b = self.get_annotation_clip()
4736
4737 if b or (b is None and self.coords1 == "data"):
4738 xy_pixel = self._get_xy(self.xy1, self.coords1, self.axesA)
4739 if self.axesA is None:
4740 axes = self.axes
4741 else:
4742 axes = self.axesA
4743 if not axes.contains_point(xy_pixel):
4744 return False
4745
4746 if b or (b is None and self.coords2 == "data"):
4747 xy_pixel = self._get_xy(self.xy2, self.coords2, self.axesB)
4748 if self.axesB is None:
4749 axes = self.axes
4750 else:
4751 axes = self.axesB
4752 if not axes.contains_point(xy_pixel):
4753 return False
4754
4755 return True
4756
4757 def draw(self, renderer):
4758 if not self.get_visible() or not self._check_xy(renderer):
4759 return
4760 super().draw(renderer)
